This game is really something incredible. I'm not big on reading, or on the sort of turn-based combat that this game uses, but I figured "what the heck, it seems fun and funny" and I tried it.
This game is sooo much more than that. It's more than all the silly jokes, or little(and big!) quests it offers. It's a whole world of opportunity of character building, and exploration, and puzzles, and adventure, and so much more! It has all of the exciting parts of a grindy-exp game, without all of the boring grindy time-wasting (yeah, it actually incorporates the grind into something that's actually fun and interesting to play! go figure!)
It really leaves goals and expectations open for the player to decide and to experience.

Let's be real: this game didn't get its high ratings for having and out-of-this-world graphical experience-of-the-century. It's all about the gameplay. And this game NAILS it.

38912009.review:
Very fun RPG. The humor is omnipresent and quite good, but what really makes the game fun is the variety in non-combat stuff. Various skills, stats, perks and items constantly present options, making them feel vibrant. There's 3 or more ways to resolve every step of the "main" quest and at least 2 for almost every notrivial sidequest. There's also creative puzzles, a battle reenactment minigame, several quests that affect the ending, and probably more I forgot.

And yes, everything in it is funny.

The combat system's not the greatest but not terrible, good enough to support the rest of the game. On the plus side the different party members and classes do feel different on a second playthrough, and there is a "hard mode" you can activate during the prologue. And replay value is unusually high for a game of this type since, as said above, there's many ways to resolve the main quest.

Overall, it's everything I'd hope for from an RPG spinoff of Kingdom of Loathing.

38845111.review: This game is patently [i]hilarious[/i]. A barrel of laughs from start to finish - the encounters, the dialogue, the perks and classes and myriad bizarre things you can find and do. I've already played through it four times and I'm still having fun. My only complaint about this game is that it is not very difficult. It's well-balanced at the beginning, but even with minimal grinding, you get strong enough to effortlessly deal with enemies pretty quickly. The only way to [i]not[/i] be overprepared for new areas, especially towards the end, is to rush through the game, and this is a game where you want to stop and smell the flowers just because those flowers are all terribly amusing. There is a hard mode, but again - it was only difficult at the very beginning. I quickly got used to it and beat the game in one day on my first attempt. Combat is easy to cheese, since you can use an unlimited number of items without ending your turn. The only way to make this game genuinely hard is to go without a partner, and that's just not any fun, since they're all fantastic (and say amusing things).

38783248.review:
West of Loathing is a celebration of stick figures, witty humour, and crazy, preciously good storytelling. It feels like indulging in a secret book stashed away at the back of the western fiction section, a book which was so imaginative and refreshing the librarian shamelessly hid it away for themselves. As a game, it aces effortless 'lazy' controls by including keyboard and mouse with seamless transitions irrespective of input. It's also an incredibly accessible RPG lite adventure that perfectly parodies turn-based mechanics and turns grinding into pure joy. Had this been a novel, we'd have been deprived of the lovely guitar melodies, echoing whistles, and that beautiful theme song that fills me with the nostalgia of a song I can't quite place. Update: I am thinking of the "Exodus" theme. 

Easily one of the most entertaining titles I've ever played, period. Also the crazy horse is such a blessing.

38757099.review:
Long story short, it's a great game.
It's basically skyrim but with humour instead of seriousness, quality over quantity, shitty turn based combat instead of shitty action combat.

1.humour
Instead of avoiding RPG shenanigans WoL embraces them and turns into humour. I love it. 

2.quality
There are plenty of side quests and every single one is somehow unique. Visiting fort might end up with opening your third eye, and recovering library book might end up with unraveling a story of love and betrayal. You never know what will happen. 

3.combat
Combat isn't the reason why you'll be coming back to west of loathing. Encounters with NPC's are core of this game, but it's the combat that marks our characters progress through the game. It's purpose is to subtly remind us how far we've come. Saying that, combat is really fun even though it's simple. If I would have to nitpick I would say that it could be a little bit faster (You can increase combat animation speed in options, but it makes animations feel unnatural).

I've managed to beat west of loathing in 14 hours, but oh boy was it time spent well. If you like skyrim and you like lighthearted humour you have to buy this game.

This game is great - I bought it on a Friday, expecting to play here-and-there, but ended up playing it straight through the whole weekend.

The combat system is simple, but elegant - if you're looking for a very hardcore experience, this might not be for you, but it has taken a simple formula and given it a number of interesting twists.

The storylines and humor is wonderful - lots of games get these wrong, but WoL delivers consistently.

My only complaint is that there is SO MUCH content to explore, and it's all several layers deeper than one would ever expect, but it is difficult to see that depth when playing through naturally. I learned much much more about the game using the Wiki than I would have liked, but it let me experience more than if I had just followed the threads I was aware of. I wish there had been a more natural way to discover all of these interesting corners of the game, but at the very least I was glad to get to see them.

38615578.review:
This is easily one of the funniest games I played in 2017.  In the 20 hours it took me to solve it the first time, I pretty much did nothing else until I had finished it, despite the fact that I was supposed to be studying.

The game is set in absurd western themed world where humour is so baked into the fabric of everything that there is virtually nothing that isn't some kind of joke.  This could easily fall flat if it were poorly written, but I found the writing to be fantastic.  Obviouslly humour is subjective so if you aren't onboard with it's humour you proably won't get much out of it.  For everyone else you are due for a hell of a ride as the game is an absolute hoot.

The game takes place in a kind of openinsh world with your character setting out from a location on their horse. You can either select to "Wander" in which case you will make a broad loop out and around, potentially unovering new map locations or encountering a random encounter.  You can also direct travel to locations you have found and will also be told about map locations from NPC's or as the outcomes of various quests.    The world is feels quite expansive with a lot of interesting locations to explore.  There are a couple of central plot quests to pursue and a bunch of side quests as well.  In my 20 hour playthrough I managed to complete the main story but still had a few side things Id managed to miss all the clues for.

Combat in the game takes place in a turn based format that should feel familiar to anyone has played a JRPG before.  You stand on one side, your foes tand on the other and you select your various attacks and abilities from a list specific to each characters class.  As you gain XP  you can choose what skills you buy so you can tailor your character to your play style, with higher skill levels costing increasing amounts of XP.  You can further personalise your character with a swathe of various equiment, almost all of which is humorous and absurd.  The combat is not particularly complex but its good enough and the humour is so good that it really does the heavy lifting for keeping you engaged.

As you can see from the screenshots the graphics portray everything in stick figures, but everything is surpisingly detailed and the great animation and the little touches really add to the charm of world.  A still screenshot doesn't really do justice to how much fun this game is to see in motion.

The music and sound are suprisingly good too, with twangy guitars and banjos mixed with good old time whistling and other wild west sounding stuffness.  Once again is better than you have any right to expect from such an overtly daft title and between the lively graphics and relelentless humour It's just another layer of polish to draw you into the games odd version of the wild west.

Look I flat out loved this game. It was a delight. As I said, your milage may vary if the humour doesn't tickle your funny bone but I can tell you now, never have I laughed so hard at a game as I did digging through the spitoons in West of Loathing.

Gold.

9 out of 10

38360676.review:
[b]West of Loathing 4/5:[/b] "[i]When you have to shoot, shoot. Don't talk.[/i]" A nebo naopak mluvte dokud nevymluvíte protistraně díru do hlavy. West of Loathing se dá lehce odbít přirovnáním k southparkovským RPGčkům [i]Stick of Truth/Fractured But Whole[/i]. Má s nimi společnou strukturu i mechanismy skrze adventurnější průzkum světa versus tahové JRPG like souboje, simplicitní (ovšem koncepčně absolutně dotaženou) vizuální stylizaci i to, že pod parodicko-satirickým odlehčeným hávem se skrývá regulérní RPG. Akorát tam, kde si druzí dva jmenovaní berou na paškál především fantasy/superhrdinská klišé, tak tam první jmenovaný operuje (nejen) s westernem, který je ve hrách stále spíše pole neorané; a v RPG žánru pak tuplem.

 Jak již bylo naznačeno v úvodu, tak nejednu situaci můžete řešit konfliktem či disputací na ostré nože. A pro první průchod hrou, který při plnění všeho zabere cca třináct hodin, doporučím druhé jmenované. Ne snad že by to bylo lehčí či že by zdejší soubojový systém nebyl zábavný (byť je časem poněkud jednotvárný a po několika hodinách se přejí; až na několik tužších soubojů), ale proto, že si při něm ještě mnohem více užijete hlavní devizu hry. Humor. Ten je sice ve hře od úvodního menu přes popisy předmětů až po dialogy, ale nejvíce vynikne právě v dialogových přestřelkách.  

 Autoři se ani nesnaží o humory na sílu a za každou cenu, což nemálo zarazí s ohledem na to, že je všudypřítomný. Převážně se to drží v mantinelech chytré i hravé práce s žánrovými westernově-rpgčkovými klišé. Většina humorů však stojí čistě na textech a v tom má tento titul velkou výhru; jeho autoři umějí psát úderné dialogy i popisy (angličtina tu rozhodně není z nejtěžších, ale hodně sází na různé významy slov, řčení, slovní hrátky apod.), které jsou opravdu vtipné. Zdá se to jednoduché a samozřejmé, přesto devětadevadesát procent titulů, které by rovněž chtěly být tuze moc vtipné, toto neumí ani zpola tak dobře. Co zpola, ze třetiny. Záhy jsem se tedy přistihl, že se culím celou dobu a bezpočtukrát se i rozesmál až k slzám.

 Tolik ke stylu hraní a humoru, ovšem to nejsem ani zdaleka jediné klady. Dalším nepřehlédnutelným je hravost a nápaditost jednotlivých lokací. Čekají na vás tucty a tucty lokací, z nichž většina je unikátní a s vlastním nápadem. Kupříkladu se budete snažit lapit gang v Potěmkinově vesnici, která jednak plně dostává svému "názvu" a druhak tím umožňuje jeden puzzle využívající tradiční westernově-groteskové klišé, čeká na vás také überbyrokratické městečko duchů, kde budete běhat od jednoho formuláře pro druhý, získávat razítka, povolení apod. A to nejsou ani ty nejpamátnější lokace, takových tu je přehršel.

 Přesto to zápory samozřejmě má. Soubojový systém, který se díky malé výzvě časem stane čistě rutinním, jsem již zmínilh. Horší však je finální akt, kde na velké ploše je jen minimum lokací, což zarazí speciálně s ohledem na to, kolik toho na stejný/menší prostor nabídly první dvě. Ani se zde nerozjede mnoho nových questů a vesměs jde o pokračování již započatých. Ovšem zdaleka nejvíce znát je to na hlavním linii, která má tak nebývale utnuté vyvrcholení, že nad tím kroutím hlavou i po dvou dohráních. Právě kvůli utnutí a prázdné mapě finální akt působí jakoby tvůrcům došel čas, finance či prostě jen nápady, rozhodně však ne jako něco, co je hotové a dodělané. 

 V kostce se tedy dá říci, že "konec špatný všechno špatné aneb jak pětihvězdičkové záležitosti finálním aktem nohy nedušínovsky podkopnout". Ovšem je to v nadsázce, protože ani onen nedůstojný závěr nepřebije fakt, že tak konstantně vtipnou a hravou záležitost se vám nepoštěstí hrát každý rok.

38165601.review:
Do you like old school adventure games? Or simplistic turn based rpg combat?
Get this game.

West Of Loathing is just as described, its combat isnt too complicated to the point you'll feel the need to max yourself out to stand a chance against bosses, its pretty straight forward. You can explore the world at your own pace (with one or two expections for story),  a TON of side missions to you that are geniuely fun with little room for any that make you feel like your just doing it for stats.

You create your own character with their class, plot motive, and name, choose your own side kick & horse, and then you sit back and let things play out.
One of the west of loathings greatest aspects has to be the interactions with other characters. While your exploring the overworld you'll find yourselves in moments when you'll have a random encounter and the game kicks in its sense of humor. You'll know what choices you would do if you were playing a game like The Walking Dead, but you'll often just pick whichever choice that would make you smile because the game clearly knows its got some jokes to it, it'll wont punish you for doing just that. if you feel like letting a skeleton continue to read his book in peace, you can walk away. if you wanna talk to him, and continue to pester him, you can go on and on until he gets mad and fights you.
thats not to say you'll read EVRYTHING. when exploring the overworld map you'll run into moments when its just the game helping you earn exp, or items. those moments become very quick to recognize and you'll just skip over text as it plays out like a common "you encountered a bad guy. FIGHT!", or "You found a dusty satchle in the sand!", until you get an actual choice. So its not like its a massive time waster.

If you want to grind and get some high stats so you can do some of the more ridiculous quests, there's places you can go. that were clearly made with the intention of players grinding in specific locations. However the game lacks any sort of auto fight mode (like earthbound or bravely defualt) to speed things up without you have to press anything other than the commands you want. Nor is there any type of battle speed to make animations shorter. its not something that'll be much of a problem, but having it would be nice for those who love going above and beyond. I wouldn't expect a game like this to really add these features, though again, those dedicated, it could save time in the long run. even if only a few seconds.

Final thoughts, is this game worth the purchase? Absoluetly. Even with the minor problems of paragraphs of text for overworld encounters, and the lack of some modern day RPG combat features, West of Loathing is a great time to be had.
10/10

38128341.review:
When one of the first perks you get in the game, just from overly-examining stuff, is a purely aesthetic perk called "Stupid Walking", chances are you're probably in for a good game. When each one of those walk cycles has their own unique sounds associated with them, you KNOW you're in for a good game.

West of Loathing is a RPG from the people who made Kingdom of Loathing, and shares its artstyle, humor, and some gameplay mechanics. Yes, the artstyle is just stickfigures and black & white graphics, but it works, surprisingly. Everything's well animated and detailed, despite the simplicity, giving it a certain nice charm. The simplicity also helps for the UI, as there's very little clutter. This helps, because your inventory gets -really- cluttered (which is a good thing, stick with me).

Gameplay is the standard "loot and talk to people" out of combat then "turn-based combat" combat. Combat's simplistic, you and your ally take a turn, then your enemies. Combat's rather easy, not only because it's easy to just out-stat your enemies with the various food, booze, and potion buffs, but also because combat items don't cost an action, thus allowing you to use as many as you need to finish off enemies. There is a hard-mode, but I've yet to try it and see how combat's on it there.
The true meat of the game lies in the out of combat stuff. There is a lot of things out in the West, and thus, a lot of writing. Every item out of the hundreds of items has a small quip of description that's worth looking at, every location seems to be handcrafted with a purpose, and the dialogue is superb. Still, there is a -lot- of writing, as said. Between exploring eldritch horrors and necromantic power you shouldn't be tackling with, to a heartwarming relationship between a lass and man-cactus hybrid, it's all smart, well-written, and humorous. The sheer volume of writing can be a slight turn off if that's not what you're into, but if you've read this far into the review, chances are you'd be the audience this game is selling to.

It's also rather nice that there's very little filler in this game. I finished it in 7 hours, but I always felt like I was doing something in those seven hours. Not like Skyrim or Fallout 4's generic caves and dungeons, everything seems to have it's own unique story or twist, and chances are you'll bump into a quest or someone that will point you towards something new. 
Not only that, but there's plenty of good puzzling to be had as well (most of it optional, if you're not the type, however), legit puzzles that get you Googling and searching about. There's little grind as well, since there's plenty of just small flavor actions and text-encounters you have traveling about that grant you XP, though there are certain locations with infinite enemy spawners, in the off-chance you do want to grind. 

It's also pretty decent to replay. The three different classes seem to play fairly differently, and there's a fair amount of different followers you can bring with you, each having different quips and dialogue, alongside the aforementioned hard mode. There may be no need to actually replay the game, however, simply due to the sheer density of content available.

While West of Loathing doesn't do much new in terms of gameplay, it makes up for it far more with it's superb writing and charm. It avoids most of the pitfalls and downsides of most typical RPG games, with very little need to grind, and very little feeling of grinding.

And only for 11 bucks? That's ridiculous, it's not even funny.

Losing a battle doesn't cost the player hours of having to replay to get to that point - refreshing in this era of "dark souls / rogue like" games  that are brutal and punishing for mistakes.

37984424.review:
TL/DR: This game is far too easy and soon gets boring. You really are only playing this game for the humour, and it is funny, but not enough so to make it worth the money or time spent in tedious gameplay. 

The battles are incredibly easy, and as you only have 1 or 2 characters, each with only a few moves, they are very repetative and boring. Within a few hours play you have a ready supply of items that can greatly boost your stats for an entire day, and moves that can kill literally any enemy in 1 or 2 turns. You also get all HP and AP restored at end of battle, so are ready to instantly win the next fight. There are so few actions ever available that you can't even try to make the battles entertaining with different tactics. When you rarely do lose a battle, rather than punishing in any way, it automatically boosts all your stats and lets you immediatly try again :S So rather than getting to retry the same battle using what you learned from the previous defeat the game just makes it easier. 

There is apparently a helmet you can find in first town to make the game harder, but why make that a hidden item? Also it prevents you taking a partner along, so the battles which are already bare-bones, boring and repatative, would be even more so with only 1 character. 

Combat aside there is a basic point and clip adventrue element going on, but even that you are simply walked through. Never any real thought involved or choice, just a case of going somewhere, talking to someone or collecting something... any time an item in the inventory or some kind of interaction is required it is immediatly suggested. 

All this game has going for it is some funny WIld West banter and a quirky style, which soon gets old when intersperced with such unrewarding gameplay.

37918213.review:
I stumbled across this on steam and immediately purchased it without a moment's hesitation.  I was not diappointed, this game brings all the fun & funny to do it's predecessor KoL proud.  

Pro's: 

All the best feels of nostalgic gaming served up with newer, fresher, meatier jokes. The turn-based battles and RPG elements are all well balanced. The quests, characters, and loot are all fun and build on the unique world created in KoL.

Con's: 

The only thing missing is what happens when the laughter stops? .....seriously, though.  One of the primary components that gave KoL its long term playability was the Ascention system.  Once you are done with your first playthrough, why go back....what drives me to test every class, every skill, every stackable gasy bean brew in order to perfect my hardcore speed runs? I want to plan out my perma-skills and long term inventory strategies like the KoL of old?  I want my STINKING badges!? Honestly, I'm hoping this was left out of the original release to be added in as part of the DLC providing "End-game" content?  Otherwise, this is an amazing game and I'm very happy to have had a chance to revisit this crazy trope filled universe.

37874845.review: From the witty makes of Kingdom of Loathing comes a western-themed Spinoff RPG. With a fully fleshed-out story, awesome soundtrack, gut-busting humor and solid gameplay, there's a lot to discover beneath this game's silly appearance of stick figures.

37858728.review:
The simplistic stick-figure art style belies a wealth of sharp-witted humor and surrealistic gameplay that most triple-A titles in the role playing genre would be too afraid to touch. The loss is their own, for I can safely say that I feel loads better every time I boot up this little gem of a game. 

The combat system is a bit simplistic, and the difference between playing one class over another (as far as written dialog) is usually one sentence, but these are not big enough problems to deter me from fully enjoying this new rendition on the Old West. It's one of the few RPGs that actually had me excited to just start exploring the game world, whether it be a lead for a story mission, or simply to wander around and see what new insanity I will find.

Best of all, since the controls are so simple (I just click with the mouse), anyone can pick up this game without getting frustrated.

I highly recommend this to any gamer that likes RPGs, loves silly humor, and enjoys a good spaghetti western.

37824414.review:
Un juego de rol con mecánica de combate sencilla, gráficos simplones pero muy descriptivos y con unas animaciones muy agradables. Su atractivo de todos modos no se encuentra en estas cosas, ni siquiera en la trama principal (de la que carece), sino en la maravillosa cantidad de pequeñas subhistorias, conversaciones y detalles. Todos los objetos y habilidades del juego, el cual tiene a porrillo, tienen una imaginativa descripción que en la mayoría de los casos como mínimo te arrancará una sonrisa. El humor absurdo y los juegos de palabras son omnipresentes y de alta calidad (eso sí, en inglés), los puzzles son entretrenidos y con sentido, y la gran cantidad de misiones, localizaciones y objetos te mantienen entretenido e interesado.

Por lo demás, tiene una temática western muy típica (y tópica), exagerada hasta el extremo en todos los detalles, que le da una riqueza ambiental muy de agradecer.

[h1]Te gustará si:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Te van los RPGs con mecánicas poco complicadas, pero con mucha atención al detalle.
    [*]Gozas del humor absurdo y los juegos de palabras (inteligentes y no tanto).
    [*]Buscas un juego de rol más chapado a la antigua con una duración intermedia-baja.
    [*]Te va el rollo del oeste.
[/list]

[h1]NO te gustará si:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Tienes un nivel bajo de inglés o te aburre leer. El juego tiene gran cantidad de texto y usa un inglés bastante elevado o de vocabulario raro con frecuencia.
    [*]Solamente disfrutas con gráficos preciosistas o 3D de última generación (eso salta a la vista en las imágenes de previsualización).
    [*]Quieres encontrarte unos personajes con épicos trasfondos deliciosamente detallados y una trama que te sorprenda o te atrape. Todo esto está supeditado al estilo western y funciona más para darle una capa de auténtico sabor del antiguo oeste americano de las películas que para contar una historia (aunque se las apaña muy bien en algunas ocasiones).
    [*]Esperas un sistema de niveles/habilidades/clases complejo y absorbente. Las habilidades son graciosas e interesantes (de hecho la mayoría de la satisfacción está en obtenerlas) pero el nivel de personalización a la hora de construir el personaje es muy bajo.
[/list]

El resumen: gran juego de rol, todo en inglés del chungo, RPG, humor extravagante, sistema de combate olvidable, enormísima ambientación.

Hablando por mí, un 9/10

哇玩这个游戏到第三张地图的时候真的痛苦到呕吐！
因为英语水平不过关，没办法读懂所有游戏文本，所以基本上无论主线支线任务都不清楚要求，只能在一个个地点之间疲于奔命。
而且一开始选择的属性极大地限制了后来的游戏，有些任务必须要求撬锁的，没从头升级撬锁属性就根本做不了。
每次换到下一张图会导致难度骤升，无论怎么加buff，第二张图任务没做完就进不了第三张图，否则分分钟被强过几倍的敌人怼死。
没办法，想完成目前的任务就不得不去看全英文攻略，那个写的简直比游戏原文还要痛苦……马戏团main show我照攻略怼了超过半个小时，仍然进不去……
都这样了，游戏还会不断通过各种方式给你增加难度，尤其第三张图那个ant eye effect直接给你扭曲画面，玩到这儿真的心态爆炸。仍然照攻略去怼了jelly bean据说可以解除这个效果，但是根本不行……不行……不行……
差评只是泄愤，游戏本身的制作和想法绝对值得好评。只能说这个游戏确实不是做给非母语的人玩的，想入手的看到这条请望而却步，省了这个钱。

37481102.review:
Seeing as how the Steam Awards encourages us to write a review, I thought of this wonderful game. There are some pros and cons to the game but it balances out really well to be an enjoyable experience. Might as well give a proper review for a proper game. TLDR at the end.

Pros:
+ It's not linear. Yes, a lot of things you do will have an effect on your ending, and that is all I would want to say without any possible spoilers.
+ Huge map to explore
+ On-point Comedy
+ The characters are VERY well wrtten. An old miner you meet early on, will foreshadow some disturbing things in the game's lore. You MUST talk with everyone in the game, some even have different dialogue after a while.
+ They make great use of every item in the game. I had to replay two times to even get some specific things, unlike most games where most of what you pick up ends up being "useless" and wares.
+ After the game's "end", the game continues and there are more stuff to finish.
+ Stupid walking. Nuff said.

Cons:
- The inventory is a huge pain in the neck to navigate. By the near end of the game, my inventory was so cluttered that my frames dropped a lot whenever I opened my inventory. Although this only happened because I like to hoard, and the drops were only for a short 2 seconds.
- Final part of the game. Without spoilers, it's kind of lackluster when you agree to give a 'specific thing'. Honestly, it's much better not to comply by that moment.

Now for some neutral points. These are neither great, nor bad. As evident above, the pros already heavily outweigh the cons, these ones are more of slight nuisances that don't really matter that much, but can help a person who read this know some key features.

Neutrals:
- Granted the game doesn't really hold your hands, but the buff system was never properly explained. You have 3 buff stats, Grit for Stomach and Pain, Gumption which is AP, Speed, and Spleen, and Glamour which is basically Drops in general and Liver. In your inventory, there are numbers that represent this, and they have slots (0/2 for example). Grit is the most important because of Pain Tolerance, so the higher the number on your Pain Tolerance is, the more you can survive when you die in combat. Every time you get knocked out, you get a perk "Angry" which increases all your stats. Food is stomach, pills/drugs are spleen, and liquor is liver.
- The automatic levelling system is not that great. It's good for balancing stats, but most people on hard mode would want to level their skills and get food buffs early on. Those and dynamites, yeah.
- The lapels. There are several armor and weapon slots in your inventory, and well, the most useless one is the lapel. Early on it's useful for around an hour then...it loses its value.
- Grinding. You can grind A LOT in this game, and while it's alright for people like me who grinds commonly in games like Diablo 3, it might be a dealbreaker to some. Keep in mind however, in no way are you required to grind.
- Crafting components are sometimes named as "Junk" or have no value at all. I'm looking at you silver cufflinks.

TLDR; It's a great game. Buy it, especially now it's on a sale, even though it is kinda low for a sale. I'm just writing this review because of the steam awards and I figured "Why not? I love this game!" This game is also best enjoyed blind, or with a friend beside you on the couch.

37276305.review:
I am someone who played Kingdom of Loathing a lot back in the day, and enjoyed it a lot. The first time I heard about West of Loathing was the day it released on Steam. At that point, I hadn't thought about KoL in YEARS, and had actually forgotten it existed. But my good memories (once I excavated them from under years of dust and rubble) were enough to convince me to buy this game on the spot for full price, which is something I virtually never do (though, really, it has a pretty low price tag, which is nice).

It was one of the best buys I've made in a long time.

This game is an RPG, and plays as such. But at its core, this game is about reading. Because, though the RPG elements are perfectly fine, and quite in-depth when it comes to this type of game, when it comes right down to it, we all love this game for the jokes.

The writing is leaps and bounds beyond any game I have ever come across (which doesn't surprise me, because KoL was the same way, and it's made by the same people). Part of the reason for the stellar writing is the, shall we say, unique art style, which some may find a turn-off. But because of the minimalist nature of the animations, a lot of actions and scenes are written out rather than animated, and it just WORKS. It works so well that I've bought this game several times over and gifted it to my friends because I just love it that much.

TL;DR

If you enjoy witty humor, reading, and RPGs, get this game for sure, whether on sale or not. Just get it.

If you prefer serious games, don't like doing a lot of reading in your gaming, or dislike turn-based RPGs, this is not the game for you.

(Also if you don't like stick figures probably don't get it, but eh, it's likely you could still enjoy it. It's great.)

36997998.review:
This is an odd, whimsical game of stick figure asthetics but deep mechanics.  You might have to choose to wield a "Mushroom-Covered Bone" or a "Bean-Iron Whisk.  Perhaps your lapel will sport a "Stylish Pocket Square" or a "Necromancers, I Hate 'Em" button?  Of course in the West you'll want a pistol at your side.  Do you use a stylin' "Army-Issue Sidearm" or a "Ghost Pistol" that you're not even sure how it is that you're holding it.  Standing in your way are such opponents as Bandits, Goblins, Clowns, Skeletons, Hellcows perhaps even... a Barrista?

There are references and puzzles in the main quest that are relatively simple and some off the beaten path that are a little more obscure.  Obscure as in military communication procedures (yes that's a hint for you).  Your choices matter.  Your stats matter.  Your willingness to cling to perfectly logical technology in an old western style does not matter.  Kick back, laugh and enjoy.  Keep your serious hat nearby.  Some puzzles may break your brain.

West of Loathing is brought to you by the makers of Kingdom of Loathing, a long running browser game with the same stick figure asthetics and even deeper mechanics and more obscure pop culture references.

36960681.review:
I have followed the development of this game for a very long time,  being a member of their previous game: Kingdom of Loathing.
There is a lot to like about this game, notably at first the humor of the writing.  The systems (mechanics) are appealing to me (RPG elements and Turn Based Combat)  and allow you to see the work and care put into the animations, which for stick figures is pretty amazing.  The soundtrack is also quite pleasing, themed in that Wild West way that brings you in to the world a little bit.
The developers have described it as "Skyrim with beans,"  which is pretty accurate in a sense that the side quests and exploration are a big part of the game rather than the main storyline.  And there are beans.
If you are looking for a game which you can laugh a little, fight a little and not feel a rush to finish then I suggest you pick up this game.

36958870.review:
Despite being a regular in the Kingdom of Loathing for several years and knowing more or less what Asymmetric was capable of when it came to writing, West of Loathing is my easy choice for SASC 2017's 'Better than Expected' Award.

And that's not even to suggest that my expectations were low coming in; I knew this was a game that I'd enjoy, but it turned out to be so much bigger and more expansive than it appeared at first glance.

For those unfamiliar with the Kingdom, the original text-based, stick-figure MMORPG prides itself on its humorous writing, puzzles and replayability. West of Loathing indeed showcases all of these with trademark charm, but does so with an additional exploration element as the development team stretches out into this different game style.

Of note, the game's simplified turn-based, combat mechanics depend heavily on how you build your character - relatively little strategy is involved when it comes to reacting to random encounters. At times, the combat feels as if it's just... there... as a means to break up the story. I've learned to treat it as a challenge in preparing for combat rather than reacting to tactics-based combat RPG encounters, and in that respect I think it works just fine.

And it's all presented in a nice little story arc that never reaches a point of going on too long, making it easy to go back and replay the game again, making different choices and seeing how the world changes.

It's a worthwhile buy for its writing alone; most who have played it include its humor and story-telling as high marks. But there's plenty more to like about West of Loathing - just don't go spoiling it for yourself before you play it!

36772175.review:
West of Loathing comes from the same folks who made Kingdom of Loathing, and boy, does it show. It's got the same largely monochrome, stick-figure art style. The classes you can play are all goofy occupations like Cow Puncher and Snake Oiler. Puns and references are abundant throughout.

Thankfully, they've still got the touch even after all this time. KoL mechanics like hunger and the three M stats, while tweaked a bit to better fit WoL's CRPG nature, made the transfer. The writing is sharp and witty, with jokes that range from the obvious to the obsure to the unexpected. There usually are multiple solutions to a problem - there's always the option to fight, but there might be alternatives if your other stats are high enough or you happen to possess a particular skill. The music is uncharacteristically dramatic for a game like this, although it does add to the hilarity when you're flinging beans at a shaving-cream-covered skeleton.

Perhaps the biggest complaint is that the ending is rather abrupt. While you arrive at a conclusion to your journey, it just comes out of nowhere, and there is a lack of a climactic anything leading up to it.

However, that is just one knock against what is otherwise an enjoyable and very funny game. Even if you've never heard of Kingdom of Loathing, this comes highly recommended.

36535948.review:
Just get it, play it, read the reviews after. Let's Plays will spoil it, play it for yourself. You'll be glad you did.

Everything about this game gives the appearance of shallowness, from the stick figures and black and white line drawings, to the silly humor, to the simple mechanics. However, there is a surprising amount of depth here for anyone who cares to dig.

It's genuinely funny, beyond the silly. A lot of the humor is pretty damned sharp, and it's clear that the creators know about serious comedy. Some of their gags are actually references to much older acts, not to mention a lot of inside jokes from the comedian community.

The silly, though, is done to perfection. There is a constant delivery of lines or actions that catch you off guard, and make you laugh unexpectedly.

The gameplay has depth, too. There is marrow beneath the bone white surface. With the fights, it's not apparent until some of the the later levels that strategy is important (it is quite possible to grind to over-level most battles, though).

Also, there is so much stuff to do and get and discover, you can't possibly experience everything without multiple play-throughs. Optimizing your skills and equipment to your play-style is easy and has a noticeable effect. Random things will pop-up too, and also things that seem random but aren't, and that helps to keep things fresh. There are a lot of adventure game puzzle elements, too, in that whole mess. They don't ever bog the game down or get you stuck, it's just more game-gravy if you want it.
It's not perfect, by any means. The music is fantastic, but incredibly repetitive. A lot of the smaller battles could be put on auto, you seriously don't need to be there for them. Grinding is a thing: it's too tempting not to do it, but incredibly boring once you get on the treadmill. As cute as the graphics are, they will strain your eyes after a while. The menu is amusing as hell, but could use some functional tweaking.

Play it for the lols, just don't be surprised if you keep playing it because it's actually quite good.

Okay, this game is rediculous. Silliness over the top, random and just a great game to chill to... 
Just know you're in for a lot, and I mean a lot, of reading parts. So don't play it on a day you just want to zone out, you'll get so much more out of it if you feel like reading, turn based combat, and a lot of exploration. There aren't really "multiple endings" in the sense that the ending changes too drastically depending on what you do, but rather the stories resolve themselves the more you finish them. You'll know what I mean when you beat it...

I recommend that you play this blind, as in not knowing beforehand what could happen... 
((If you're actually blind, well... I'm curious how you play video games... Especially ones that rely mostly on visual reaction...... Anyway...))
I admit I found this one by a playthrough on youtube, so I feel most of the surprises, and mystery of it wasn't quite all there when I played it myself, but I did manage to know some things to look out for in order to figure some of the fun stuff out with the strange robot tech stuff... It's really difficult not to spoil anything here, I fully recommend you play it through, and just do whatever crazy thing you so desire. Meddle with the dark arts of necromancy, kill all the outlaws, or just go about doing good. It's all up to you, and more!

If you found this before watching a "lets play" or anything, just trust me. Play it, do everything, leave no stone unturned. And once you've explored it to your satisfaction and beaten the game. Then go watch someone play it if you want... You'll just get that much more from experiencing it without knowing anything. The less you know going in, the better everything is!

36005607.review: West of Loathing may not look very good based on its stick figure art style, but don't let that fool you the game has solid animations that fit with the game and avoids looking like some cheap stick figure game made in 2009. The animation and simplistic style combined with the witty writing, that comes from the developers years of experience working on the Kingdom of Loathing, makes the game a something that will at least get a few smiles out of you. The Game also has a surprising amount of choices that combined with its relatively short main questline and cacophony of side quests make it into something that has lots of replayability. Overall, West of Loathing is a game well worth its low price tag.

35584822.review:
This is my review for the West of Loathing. -WARNING- This review contains spoilers. -WARNING-
I haven't played much of the Kingdom of Loathing, but I prefer this game to the kingdom alot more. So first off,

Combat - 9/10 - The combat in this game follows a standard turn based combat system, with multiple statistics for each enemy, and multiple attacks especially for you. However, on standard mode, you can easily farm experience to become exeptionally stronger than your enemies. Luckily, hard mode, which can be enabled via a hat, called the Hard Hat, obtained in the prologue of the game.

Companions - 7/10 - There are five companions in this game, not counting the temporary summoned ones. Your main companion is obtained through the prologue, and there is an additional companion unlocked in the buffalo pile, named Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Bill. Buffalo Bill cannot be controlled by the player, adding a wild card to combat. He does not appear out of combat and the initial discovery, and is completely optional and easy to miss. The other companions appear in and outside of companions, and will make comments on locations, or mark locations on your map matching their area of expertise. 
Susy Cochrane is a former rancher, and will mark ranch themed locations on your match. She utilises a rifle in combat, doing damage to individual enemies. She also can unlock a lasso skill, temporarily stunning enemies, and gains exp from killing cows. 
Doc Alice is a doctor obsessed with the undead, and will mark graveyards on the map. She utilises a shotgun in combat, doing little damage to mulitple enemies. She can also unlock an attack that will instantly kill skeletons, yet is useless against other enemies. She gains exp from killing skeletons, but will also leave you if you become the Necromancer at the end of the Necromancer side quest. 
Crazy Pete is a former miner, who has gone insane. He will mark mines on your map. He uses an attack that does hot damage to an enemy, which can be exeptionally good, or next to useless depending on the enemy. He likely has another attack, but I honestly haven't played with him that much, and never leveled him up enough to unlock his other attacks. He gains instant levels, via random encounters.
Gary the Goblin is a goblin, and will mark goblin occupied locations on your map. He uses an attack that does little damage, but he preforms the attack multiple times. He can unlock another attack, producing an identical copy of himself with slightly worse stats. He gains instant levels by you purchasing "Shroom-Gro" and giving it to him. This obviously the most expensive companion in the game, as Shroom-Gro multiplies in price every time you buy it, but also the most comical.

Replayability - 4/10 - I have played this with each companion and class, and while there are choices in the game, you really only have to play this game three times to experience everything, which is why it gets a low rating. If the developers would update this game like they frequently did with KoL, it would surely add to the longevity and replayability of this game. There is DLC to this game, however it is simply bought in KoL and unlocks cosmetic horse armour. It really doesn't do anything. In comparison, I've spent 59 hours in this game, and 413 hours in Fallout 4, which is a game everybody should buy.

Exploration - 8/10 - This is an open world game, meaning you can visit anywhere you want, when you want. The map is unlocked in four parts. The proluge, and then the main area, divided into three seperate areas. You unlock the areas by firstly completing the prologue, then progressing through the main questine will unlock the other two areas. There are alot of locations to discover, and is very fun. However, as I said before, updates and/or DLC would definitely make the game better and more expansive. 

Storyline and Quests - 8/10 - There are many little side quests and three main storylines. The side quests consist of trapping the infernal Duke Bovicus, leader of the satanic cows, tracking down items to summon a shiny skeleton named Dave, and locating skeletons for the Petting Cemetary. The three main storylines consist of helping the railway reach the town of Frisco, which serves to unlock the map in the WoL. There's also the El Vabrito questline, which is the player attempting to save the world of Loathing by repairing the containment for an evil diety called Roberto, who will destroy loathing if the containment fails in 420 years. Lastly, is the necromancer questline, which consists of the player attempting to find clues to the location of the Necromancer, who is terrorizing the world of Loathing with his undead army. It ultimately ends with the player eaither destroying the Necromancer, stopping the necromancer from raising more of the dead, or becoming the Necromancer and taking the army for yourself, if you have enough skill in Nex-Mex.

Final Rating - 7/10 - A very good game, with lots of intentionally bad jokes. As I've said multiple times before, however, DLC and/or updates would definitely make this game alot better. Still, if are contemplating buying it, I highly recommend it.

Whoooo-eee padner, you're in for a rip roarin' good time!

Full disclosure: I was a player of the original "kingdom of loathing" for many years, so take this as coming from a seasoned Seal Clubber with a couple ascensions under his belt.

Pros
------ 
- Simple enough to play while half asleep, but tactical enough that your choices in comabt and on the map matter

- Pun-tastic

- Very High "Fun Factor", in the vein of the Stick of Truth

- Actually interesting story and characters for a game mainly based on humor

- Soundtrack that is both reminiscent of and at the same time better than most of the classic "spaghetti westerns"

Cons
------

- Repetitive

- Random and not in a good way 

- Hard mode isn't so much "hard" as "you're not allowed to grind except random encounters and enemies have more health" mode, which basically makes the game much more repetitive and frustrating, but not much more difficult.


Overall a fantastic experience that is guarenteed to make you laugh while playing. Reccomended to fans of low-complexity RPGs in general, and a no-brainer for fans of the Stick of Truth.

35435305.review:
West of Loathing is an rpg that relies heavily on it's writing and world building. That being said it does a wonderful job doing both of theses things, using a combination of word play and incredibly humourous moments. the game gives you a little choice at times which is always welcome, it's nothing major, just a few dialouge diffferences and maybe different fights and loot. 

I probably don't need to tell you this, but the graphics are not anything to go crazy over. The game seems to be aware of this fact though, and embraces it, a very "when life gives you lemons aproach." the music and sound effects feel very fitting for a western setting, the bangs of bullets and twangs of the backround music really compliment the atmosphere nicely. Every attack and action feels like it has some weight thanks to the sound design.

The gameplay loop is simple, find a new location, explore it, loot it, laugh, and repeat. offering a large amount of sidequests on the way. The gameplay is at it's strongest early on, when you feel vurnerable, like anything can go wrong at any second. Early fights are moderately challenging. later on sadly, the game becomes obsurdly easy, I 3 shot the final boss. however form my understanding, there is a hard mode in the game, you just need to find it. 

So yeah, I quite enjoyed west of loathing, the game making me laugh sevreral time and offering a genrally pleasent experience.

[h1] 진정한 게임 [/h1]

요즘 게임들이 하나같이 퀄리티 높고 용량을 많이 잡아먹고 있는 바람에 조선컴을 쓰는 나로써는 바탕화면에 내가 구매한 스팀 게임을 5개 이상으로 깔아보질 못했고, 툭하면 튕기기도 하고 내 생각되로 안되는 플레이에 스트레스가 쌓이곤 했다. 그런데 이 게임은 요즘 게임들과는 다르게, 그다지 용량도 잡아먹지 않으면서도 심플하고 병맛넘치며, 서부극의 건맨을 동경하곤 했던 초딩 시절을 떠올리게 해주는 여러모로 마음 편한 게임이었다.

타인보다 앞서나가기 위해 가장 효율적인 선택을 해야만 하는 게임들과는 달리, 한때 즐겨했고 지금도 가끔 즐기곤 하는 스타듀 밸리처럼 그 어떤 트롤링이나 호구짓을 하더라도 문제가 될 것이 없다. 플레이어가 최선의 선택을 하지 않더라도 최고의 결과가 나올수 있는 게임. 이보다 더 좋은 게임이 있을까? 난 이 게임을 산 지 하루도 채 되지 않았지만, 밤을 샐 정도로 몰입하고 있었다. 영어를 잘하지 못해서 스토리고 뭐고 이해는 가지 않았지만 그럼에도 즐거웠다.

타인과의 경쟁에서 뒤쳐지는 것으로 인한 스트레스를 받고 있었던 나에게 이 게임은 구원이었다. 정말로 스트레스를 풀어주는 진정한 '오락'이었고, 진정한 '게임'이었다. 타인보다 앞서가며 성취감을 느끼며 게임을 즐기는 타입의 사람들과는 맞지 않을지도 모르지만, 호구같은 선택과 진심어린 트롤링을 통하여 다양한 병신짓을 보고 웃으면서 게임을 즐기고 싶다면 이 게임을 강력히 추천한다.

35241470.review:
As KoL helped me slog through a few years at a very unpleasant job, I felt obligated to play WoL, as some sort of absolution. I have since repaid my debt (to my satisfaction), and will now celebrate by mixing myself up a tasty Corpse Island iced tea.

But seriously...

Should you, dear reader, be mulling whether or not to play this game, then let me say this: The writing is strong, the world is  more vast than it seems at first, and your choices affect your experience in ways both subtle and not. And don't let the simplistic art fool you -- this game is highly atmospheric. (The music helps a lot, in that regard.)

This is a game where you can take a fairly direct path from beginning to end, if you wish. Along the way, however, you'll encounter numerous seemingly-loose threads just waiting to be pulled; if you do so, you'll find yourself going down the various rabbit holes that exist in this game. Some are small (for example, a small collection of clues to a puzzle waiting to be solved), while others are quite vast.

The joy of WoL is following each of those threads to completion, and finding all the possible resolutions that are available, be they interesting, silly, confusing, new pieces of equipment, etc.

I mentioned earlier that your choices will affect the game. This isn't taken lightly in WoL...so if you want to experience everything this game has to show, expect to play through it multiple times.

If this sounds good to you, then WoL should make for a fine purchase indeed.

35237283.review:
A few disclaimers before I begin: 

1. I had never heard of Kingdom of Loathing prior to discovering this game, and as such I have never played it before.  
2. I bought this because I watched a let's play of the beginning bits and my curiosity was piqued.  I highly recommend that if this game sounds like something you want to buy, *do not* do this.  You do not want the feeling of "Oh I've heard this joke before," as the comedy is worth experiencing for the first time on your own.

Overview:
After picking a name and gender for your character, you are given the option of magic-wielder, melee fighter, or a rogue/thief class.  (For the record, in my one playthrough I have completed thus far, I picked magic).  Your character has decided to leave your family's farm to go west, where small towns and demon cows are awaiting.  That's basically all of the story in a nutshell.

THE GOOD:

- Laugh-Out-Loud Funny  

Seemingly everything has a goofy description, a peculiar story, or is just a strange thing in general that will probably make you crack a smile.  This humor is not high-brow, but it doesn't have to be.  If you allow it, this story will make you laugh.  The game thrives on player exploration, so you are doing yourself and the game a disservice if you do not check out everything you can.

- Surprisingly Open-Ended

Instead of formal levels, the progression in this RPG is mostly through using XP to increase stats.  In a way very reminiscent of Fallout, having certain stats a high enough level will allow you to avoid the game becoming a series of never-ending fights, while also hiding some of the game's best gags.  Of course, no one will blame you if you mercilessly fight everything that looks at you sideways either.  The game shows you this choice early on when you are first given the option to kill a bandit or talk him out of his life of crime.  Not only that, but the short time you spend with side characters while helping them with their varying problems does often lead to actually helping them.  There's a strange amount of impact you leave on the small game world.  

- Intuitive, Easy Combat

This is as simple to grasp as it gets. Fighting is standard turn-based fare, with melee weapon, gun, and magic attack options.  Each fight you start with a certain amount of AP which you use to cast spells, but guns and melee weapons are unlimited.  Characters are on a grid, but this really serves no change in combat.  Guns become blocked off by cover (either yours or your enemies) or another enemy standing in front of your target.  Because magic and melee still work in these cases, however, I can't say this made much difference.

- Interesting and Likeable Characters  

From the most evil enemies to your choice of "pardner," every npc in this game has an adorable charm.  Part of it is of course the stick figure aesthetic, but characters stand out for their quirkiness and deadpan acceptance of the ridiculous world they live in.  Some moments with characters are even downright sad in spite of the obvious comedic theme.  One character that you choose from a few options follows you throughout the game as your "pardner" and fights in combat with you.  Each of these characters was interesting and I wanted them to go with me for different reasons.  Hearing their dialogue and using their abilities is warranting of multiple playthroughs, as far as I see it.  


THE BAD:

- Little Quest Variety

Almost every mission, whether it's part of the main quest or not, is at the heart of it a fetch quest.  Characters have lost this or that, or had it stolen, and it's up to you to find it (and you'll probably have to kick some ass to get to it).  The game seems to make fun of itself for this late in the game during one of the main story missions, with your main character actually getting pretty frustrated at a particularly ridiculous endeavor.  For me though, this was just a reminder of how I was beginning to grow tired of the superficiality of the actual tasks I was doing.  I often used the ability to ask my "pardner" where I was supposed to go next for the various side missions just because I started getting bored of quests and would go off exploring instead.

- Combat Growing Tedious

As I said previously, I played the magic-casting "beanslinger" class so my best attacks were spells that I learned from books I found throughout the world.  Once I had found a combo of spells that allowed me to take a good chunk of health from an enemy in turn one, there was no reason to do anything else.  Battles started to become all the same, and I started spacing out while doing them just to get to more of the funny dialogue.  One particular annoyance came in a fight which had three enemies attacking me and 2 others buffing the whole team's attack and defense each turn.  I had to kill the attackers first so that I wouldn't be killed (more an annoyance that anything, as you can come right back), but this left the other two enemies with 100+ hp health bars buffing themselves into oblivion.  By the time I was fighting only them, they had buffed themselves so much that I could only do 1 damage at a time to them, and had to just speed up the combat speed in the options menu and wittle them both down one at a time.  This is of course a worst-case scenario, but as I said just going through the motions once you are super strong quickly becomes the worst part of the game.

THE UGLY:

-The Ending (NO SPOILERS!) 

The game just sort of ends once you complete the last mission of the "main" storyline.  You are free to watch the ending cutscene, as well as go right back into the world and complete any remaining sidequests, but there's something so dissatisfying about it.  It's a feeling of reading a very good joke book, and the empty feeling you get when you close the back cover.  


TL;DR, West of Loathing is game that is a solid RPG that just barely overstays its welcome.  It's hilarious for people who don't mind some simple humor, but the game design could have used a bit more complexity.  

If you don't mind an RPG not being very deep in its mechanics and instead being a charming, ridiculous world, West of Loathing is your game.  You're either going to play it once, enjoy it, but never feel a need to play it again, or want to try every "pardner" and replay for hard mode and show all of your friends.  

For the low price, the length and potential replayability, and the enjoyment I personally got from it, I can whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone looking for a chill time and a good laugh.

35195905.review:
The funniest thing that's happened to me in 2017. 

I see many reviews comparing it to Fallout, and that's not surprising. On the surface it's a silly looking game with stick figure art, but underneath it has a lot in common with early Fallout games. There are different approaches to a problem based on your skill set, the random crap you find in crates is actually interesting, and I frequently encountered an experience that only the best games can give you: surprise. 

I'm into my second playthrough. Some of the jokes are not as funny the second time, but 1) in spite of that they're still funny, and 2) I'm finding things I missed before. And of course I'm playing a Beanslinger now, which makes the combat... different. And I've taken a different pardner, which also changes things up a bit. 

At the core, beneath the satire and absurdity, it's technically, well, I'd have to call it a JRPG. Yes, really. But, like, a good one. It's like if you took only the good things about a JRPG and dumped the rest. Grinding is strictly optional and random encounters are something to mostly look forward to instead of dread. 

The bad: hammers are quite expensive. There are puns.

Welcome to Loathing! If you've been around the Kingdom before, please allow a few moments for your corporeal self to adjust to the transition from text to animation. If you're  a KoLMafia user, you'll be glad to see an abundance of that blue text that tells you what stuff does when you're making decisions. If you're big on referencing the KoLWiki during your travels, a quick google search will show you that there's one out here, and the West doesn't have to be seat-of-your-pants-blind-flying wild unless you want it that way. Also note that Ascension doesn't happen here; you have but one life to live per save game. Like the full Kingdom, this game does benefit from more than one playthrough (how else will you ever own all the horses?!), and is totally worth the admission price of 1.1 Mr. Accessories.
If you haven't been to the Kingdom before, please allow several hours for your spiritual self to adjust to our denser than normal textual and contextual humor and our puzzles that may take a few tries to solve. Keep your eyes peeled, look at everything you pick up, use google or check out a guide if you get stuck (KoL has always had a lovely and active community of smart, sweet people), and don't forget to have a good time.

35140717.review:
West of Loathing is a lot of things, but what it is most of all is an epic Stickman Western. Part Spaghetti Western, part Eastwood Western, part Monty Python, but all fun and hilarity.

[h1]Story[/h1]

The story in West of Loathing is one of love and loss. You are the witty protagonist, a stick man teen set off from his family’s home to explore the world. Unfortunately, Cows from Hell are rampaging all along the countryside, and so you begin investigating that while simply exploring your world, meeting new stick people and forming friendships (and enmities) along the way.

The comedy in West of Loathing never relents, and is very much in the fusion of Clint Eastwood meets The Holy Grail. Of course, this is a western, but the memes and pop culture references also never relent, and to optimal effect. The writing is just awesome, tongue in cheek, and hilarious.

9 out of 10

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

West of Loathing is a stickman game, and so you can expect sketch art as the medium of expression here. Mostly black and white, minimalist sketch art. Again, this is done to optimal effect and it really becomes endearing and comfortable. While the artwork is sparse, it is as evocative as it is effective. Also, the style really assists in the healthy serving of sarcastic exposition you will encounter throughout.

9 out of 10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay in West of Loathing is really a combination of 2-D open world exploration and JRPG style combat.

There is an overlay map, from which you will explore the open terrain finding towns, old mines, ranches, forts, and other random spots. The 2-D map, from which you will handle direct exploration, combat, dialogue, and so on is set up in pretty basic fashion. You have your base areas and then buildings/caves/etc…that you can explore. No one area  is very large, but each makes complete sense as far as its design goes and fits perfectly with the overall theme of the game.

The combat system is handled in traditional JRPG style face offs with some very forgiving RNG’s (random number generators), base attacks, special attacks, and of course item usage. It’s actually a pretty easy game and you really shouldn’t die very often.

To assist in this, you have an infinite number of inventory slots with which to carry the various  weapons, limited use items (such as food and drink for buffs, items which cause specific types of damage, healing objects, lockpicks, and of course crafting materials.

Crafting is an essential part of this game and you will craft a lot of items through the course of your adventure. It happens in a variety of ways as well. For example, you will need a stove to bake bans, a silversmiths table to craft silver bullets and lockpicks, etc...

Additionally, you can and will build relationships, via conversations and/or side quests. The side quests often poke fun at the standard RPG tropes by making you do them almost to the point of exhaustion while also making fun of the situation as you do. In fact, this game in general is about breaking down and making fun of the RPG standards.

There is actually quite a bit more to this surprisingly deep game, but I’ll leave off for now.

9 out of 10

[h1]Audio[/h1]

The audio is actually done to perfection. From the ambient sounds you would expect from a western to music that would fit in any Clint Eastwood film, you are in for a treat with regards to the audio in West of Loathing.

10 out of 10

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

West of Loathing is a game that, simply by appearance, can be easily dismissed. However, that would be a mistake as it actually ended up being an excellent game worthy of at least on and possibly even two or three playthroughs. You will be doing yourself a favor by picking this one up.

9.3 belligerent and drunk stick man horses out of 10 possible. The other .7? Well….they say you sometimes lose a bit of yourself when you get THAT drunk.

Would 100% recommend for anyone who likes casual gameplay with great humour!

This would also make a very good console port.

35135793.review:
West of Loathing is a game that needs no twenty paragraph long review.

The basic premise of the game is that you're going out West to find your fortunes, help people, or just get off your boring farm and do something fun for once.

[b]Gameplay[/b]:

Combat is simplified turn-based. You have a number of "Action Points" that let you do special actions on your turn and they refresh between battles, and once you're out during combat you can either snort some smelling salts or just do basic attacks. It's so easy that you could probably expect a ten year old to grasp it within a minute or so. 

There are 3 classes in the game you can be and they all get their own style of fighting. They're your standard archetypes of fighter, mage, and thief. You can also have a "pardner" NPC that helps you out in combat whom can also level up with you. They all fight in their own way as well, so you have some incentive beyond just reading their unique dialog to pick a new one each playthrough.

If you're looking for hardest game ever, look elsewhere. The combat here is easily cheesed once you find the first "grinding" zone near the starter town, which lets you attack a group of enemies forever to grind out XP to level up. Plus, combat items don't end your turn if they're used, so you could stock up on poisons and dynamite to obliterate every enemy in your way.

For people who want a harder game, there is a hard mode that can be unlocked in the prologue. You can also intentionally forgo having a pardner join you in the game if you enjoy having harder combat and less funny dialog. 

Levelling up is done either by auto-levelling (Don't do this) or by point buying via accumulated XP. There are several skills you can level up, some of which are unique to which class you pick. Further skills can be picked up in-game by reading skill magazines that you will lose every single time after reading them just once. But fear not: You can easily acquire every skill in the game and still have a few skill books left over.

[b]Story[/b]:

The story is simple, like much of the game. You're out West, you're trying to get to Frisco, and there's baddies and obstacles in the way. However, the main quest is not all there is to do. There's a lot of sidequests to do, each with their own little story to tell, and this is where the game REALLY shines.

The writing is absolutely fantastic. Unless you have no sense of humor, I guarantee that the game will make you laugh quite a few times, and merely sensibly chuckle some other times. Your potential pardners all have unique dialog and their own personal stake in one of several sidequests in the main game. Everything in the game is designed to give you a good laugh and enjoy yourself, so it's wise to go into this game not taking anything too seriously.

Once you reach the end of the game (This takes about 8 hours if you're insistent on doing every single thing possible in the most timely manner, it can be much shorter if you beeline through the main quest) you're allowed to continue adventuring and completing sidequests. However, there ARE multiple endings, of a sort! Depending on which sidequests you complete and how you complete them, the ending cutscene will change! Don't expect some big world shattering difference to occur that rocks you to your core, but at least know that the game will acknowledge that you did indeed bother to fulfill sidequests and change your ending for it.

[b]Overall[/b]:

If you like funnyman writing filled with sarcasm and snark and aren't looking for a game that intends to really "challenge" you outside of hard mode, this game is for you. There's plenty of locations to visit and sidequests to do, certainly enough to kill an afternoon or two. You can also get some replay value out of the game via achievements (There is no way to get every single one in one or two playthroughs), hard mode, classes, and selecting a new pardner.

If you end up enjoying the game, I'd also recommend you pay a visit to the Kingdom of Loathing itself. Unlike this game, it does not cost money to play but it still delivers on the humor.

I see a lot of people comparing this game to Fallout, which is odd. It's absolutely NOTHING like Fallout. With that said, it's a very entertaining game. It feels like a web game on crack. Imagine your typical entertaining web game, however, unlike those games, this game has all the meat those are missing. The games main strength seems to be the humor. I'm not a huge fan of games that focus more on being funny than gameplay, but this game succeeds. Also, all the characters you meet throughout the game are all very charming. Nothing is done to death, and you get just enough of everything to keep you  satisfied. 

However I definitely have some gripes. It's entirely way too easy. It almost feels like I'm watching a video because of how easy it is. There really isn't anything to discover, because everything is right out in the open. The game is short. You can't tell by my played time, but a simple "How Long to Beat West of Loathing" will tell you it only takes about 12 hours. 

Overall, the small price tag, the charming writing, and the general feel of the game makes me able to recommend it to others. I do hope they plan to add more content down the road. 

If you want a number score, based on the ambiguity of my review, I'd give it a 6.5 to 7 out of 10. I don't understand the Overwhelmingly Positive reviews, as this game is CERTAINLY not for everyone.

35055201.review:
This is the best computer role-playing-game I've ever played. It's like one of those old-timey DOS RPGs that you always say you're going to go back and play, except when you finally do it's so abstruse and clunky and old-fashioned that you end up dying in the first encounter, or unable to figure out how to get out of the first town, so you quit after 20 minutes.

It's like that, except it's actually accessible and playable, with an interface that you understand how to use just by looking at it. It still has all the good stuff about those old RPGs that everyone raves about: worldbuilding, a boatload of secrets and mysteries to unravel, multiple ways to solve problems, skill checks out the wazoo, bad graphics, exciting loot, a million viable ways you can build your character, and a rewarding tactical turn-based combat system. It's also the funniest game I've ever played, which is a low bar, but WoL grabs that brass ring and races past the finish line with it faster than Superman can mix this metaphor.

If you like computer role-playing games you should play West of Loathing.

One erratum (9/22/17): If you want the rewarding tactical turn-based combat, make sure you equip the hard hat. Otherwise the battles are pretty trivial. If you do put the hard hat on, make sure you select the option to distribute your XP manually instead of letting the game allocate it for you. The game would still be fantastic and well worth the price of admission if you just want to breeze through the combat and explore the world, but for me personally the challenging combat and the decisions I had to make when building my character added an extra layer of enjoyment to the game.

35052648.review:
A fun RPG with a lot of replay value if you are a fan of the humour, puzzle and story aspects that this title can provide. If you are a fan of Kingdom of Loathing then this is a must for your steam library; West of Loathing will play in almost the exact same way but with actual animations and sounds rather than hopping from page to page as you do in KoL,

When starting; you will a choice of three classes four horses and four "pardners"; "pardners" range from an alcoholic doctor to an excitable goblin called Gary. Classes include cowpuncher, beanslinger and snakeoiler. Each of which have their own benefits and group with certain "pardners" better than others. And horses provide certain perks such as finding more destinations faster. Also during the prologue; be careful; the things you say will have an affect on your character.

This game is rather heavy on the amount of reading that you will need to do as there are no voice actors and choices made will affect gameplay/story as well as the ending of the game,

I would also recommend this game if you are a fan of point and click games and the type of humour that usually comes with them. In a nutshell its dad humour, dry over the top jokes that make you ashamed of yourself just for laughing at them.

If you decide to purchase this, Your first playthrough should take somewhere between 10 and 15 hours providing that you are reading everything and not just skipping conversations and then asking your "pardner" what to do.

Also if you are looking for a challenge there is a hard (hat) Mode,

10/10.

So, I played this game six times in a row... I'm not even joking.  There are two reasons I did this: 1) achievements and 2) this game is ridiculously fun and entertaining.  I've spent basically 82 hours playing this game and I had fun each and every time I did it!  Seriously, even though I was basically doing the exact same things as I'd done before over and over, I still thoroughly enjoyed playing.  Which lead me to question how in the world I didn't get tired of the game even remotely.  I came up with a list to answer that question, which I will now share.  

I think a large part of it is the sheer amount of humor in the West of Loathing.  Humor and puns are practically the lifeblood of this game!  There's so much attention to detail, from the bigger stuff like the quests and missions to the smaller stuff like random encounters and even minute details like the personalization of tombstones and notes!  Every single character that appears in the game is unique.  What's more, the way you play and the choices you make affect literally everything in the game, from how the story ends to the encounters you have and the way you handle them.  In all of my playthroughs of this game (and I intend to do at least one or two more), there seemed to always be something new.

I so highly recommend West of Loathing.  This game is ridiculously fun and I don't think one could ever grow bored of playing it.  One of the best games I've ever played!

The puzzles / riddles are awesome and quite hard sometimes but always fair. From typical item puzzles to cryptography-based riddles and messing around with alien portals - this game has it all.
It feels like decisions in this game really make a difference because there's no way to go back to an older save, the autosave is really quick. Played it during the same time as a friend and our stories turned out quite different.
The content is well worth the price, it took me 32 hours to complete the game and though I took my time exploring and riddling, I know I didn't see everything.

The only downside is that the turn-based fights are insanely easy, I'd recommend to basically anyone to play this game in hard mode.


Overall a 9 out of 10 for me and it instantly became one of my favorite adventures.

So, there are basically two audiences for this game.

The first audience are the fans of the long-running browser-based free-to-play over-hyphenated MMORPG [i]Kingdom of Loathing[/i].  If you like [i]KoL[/i], just get the game.  Speaking as an 11+ year player, you'll enjoy it.

The second audience are people who have not played [i]KoL[/i], but enjoy any of the following: turn-based RPGs, classic RPG character classes, clever and referential humor in the vein of [i]Mystery Science Theater 3000[/i], the number 11, deep game exploration, item collection, worshipping our Lord Roberto, character customizing, and/or stick figures.  If some of the above tick your boxes, give [i]West of Loathing[/i] a try.  You won't be disappointed.

Even if you're not a veteran of Kingdom of Loathing, West of Loathing stands on its own merits well enough to easily warrant its asking price.

This game isn't particularly long, but there's enough content and binary choices to warrant multiple playthroughs. On an initial blind play through you'll get 6-8 hours of enjoyment, although less if you power through to the end... but what's the point of that? The strength of this game is its hilarious writing which rivals any other comedy video game. 

It's not particularly deep from a mechanical perspective, and it's not particularly long. But it's a laugh riot without relying on its existing Kingdom of Loathing lore, and for 11 bucks it's an easy, easy recommendation.

West Of Loathing เป็นเกมผจญภัยแบบภาพขาวดำและเกมแนว Turn Based ในแนวแบบคนเส้นหรือ Stickman ซึ่งย้อนยุคไปในสไตล์ Cowboy สไตล์การเล่นคือเล่นไป ตีมอนไป ทำเควสต่างๆเพื่ออัพเวล,หาเงินและดำเนินเรื่องราวของตัวเราเอง ในเกมก็มีอาชีพพร้อมกับ status ต่างๆให้อัพแนวตามอาชีพที่เราเลือก

อาชีพทั้งหมดมี 3 อาชีพคือ
1.Cow Puncher ตามชื่ออ่ะครับ เน้นใช้กำลังตัวเองเป็นหลักในการต่อสู้และแก้ปัญหาต่างๆ(รวมถึงเควสอื่นๆด้วย)
2.BeanSlinger เป็นสายเวทที่เชี่ยวชาญเวทในเรื่องถั่ว(ใช่ครับ ถั่ว...)มาพร้อมกับปัญญาเจ้าเล่ห์ในการหาทางออกเรื่องต่างๆด้วย
3.Snake Oiler เป็นสายที่เชี่ยวชาญความแม่นปืนพร้อมกับความพยายามที่จะสกัดน้ำมันจากงู(อย่าถามเถอะ)เพื่อมาใช้ผสมในการทำยาต่างๆจากน้ำมันงู(อย่าถามอันนี้ด้วย)

อาชีพต่างๆนี้ก็จะมาพร้อมกับ status ที่คู่ควรกับอาชีพที่เราเลือก และทุกๆครั้งที่เลเวลเพิ่มขึ้นก็จะให้ค่า EXP สะสมไว้อัพสเตตัสต่างๆที่เกมกำหนดไว้ให้ หรือจะเก็บไว้อัพด้วยตัวเองก็ได้ครับ

แน่นอนว่าถ้าผจญภัยคนเดียวอาจจะเหงา เกมนี้ก็มี Pardner หรือเพื่อนร่วมทางที่สามารถผจญภัยไปกับเราได้พร้อมช่วยเหลือเราเมื่อเจอปัญหาต่างๆ แต่เราก็สามารถไปผจญภัยคนเดียวได้

ในเกมก็จะมีเหตุการณ์ต่างๆพร้อมกับมุขตลก 100 กว่ามุข(ซึ่งแทบจะเป็นมุขภาษาอังกฤษทั้งหมด หวังว่าคงเข้าใจนะ) และหมวกให้สะสมกว่า 50 หมวกพร้อมกับอาวุธที่มากมายในเมื่อง ในเหมือง ในป่า ในสุสาน แม้แต่ในโถทิ้งเสลด(จริงๆ ถ้ากล้าเอาก็ต้องกล้าทนความสกปรกด้วย 555+)

แน่นอนว่าบทวิจารณ์อย่างเดียวมันตัดสินภายลักษณ์ของเกมไม่ได้หมดหรอกครับ แต่ผมแนะนำว่าเกมนี้เป็นหนึ่งในเกมที่ดีที่สุดที่ผมเคยเล่นมาเลยล่ะครับ

34749792.review:
This is an awesome, ridiculous game full of secrets and fun.  If you're even thinking about playing it, though, don't watch too many YT vids of it or they'll ruin all the fun for ya. ;)

It's by the same crew that runs Kingdom of Loathing, and clearly has all of the KoL-esque humor and ridiculousness.

I actually like it better than KoL, and I played that for ~8 years, because I'm more interested in plot and humor than combat mechanics - and the savegames are simple JSON files (translation: easily-read and easily-edited text files).  So, if you manually back up the savegame before you do something risky, you can explore all your options.

One minor point against, which manually backing up your saves 'fixes', is that the game generally reacts well to "bad" choices - sometimes, the more screwy the choice, the better the result - except when it doesn't pay off, and then you can manually reload your save.

Side-note: If you're a completionist, expect to play thru at least four times.

Last thing to be said: If you like goofy, fun things, buy it fer cert - if you at least like fun things, buy it on sale.

(edit: Fixed a typo, just because because ;) )
