34744319.review:
One of the best games out there. Great fun and excellent writing from start to finish—especially if you're a fan of puns...

I'll spare you a clumsy attempt of my own (let's pretend I struck out... ba-dum. dsh) and leave you with the pros. West of Loathing has got you covered. It's both bigger and deeper than it appears on first glance. It's silly and wacky and it has heart... Er, I mean, grit. The art style is endearing and often plays off of (and enhances) the writing and storytelling; Seriously, you'll never care as much about the fate of one cactus-slash-man as you will here. And though the endearing style, you're peppered with a good amount of tough choices along the way.

The combat is its weakpoint. Though fine for the most part and mechanically sound, it does feel like a missed opportunity and could have done with a fair bit of adjustment and far more play-testing. Much too early (like, within one 1/15 of the game) did the fights become trite and, mostly, a question of getting things over with (which also seems to be the case in the playthroughs I've seen online). However, there is the rumour of a hard (and a hardest) mode; I never found the option, so maybe I missed it or it only becomes vailable on a second playthrough. The good news, I suppose, is that this is, above all a game that can do with a second (maybe even a third?) playthrough.

34729625.review:
- The graphics are incredibly minimalistic.

- There's so much reading it's basically a text adventure.

- The battle system can be broken pretty much immediately and you will face nary a challenge in the whole game.


And you know what? None of that crap matters. Rarely has a game made me this consistently smile all the way through. The writing is hilarious and despite dipping into toilet humor here and there it never feels cheap or mean spirited. The characters are charming and memroable. Doc Alice is maybe the most interesting companion i've had since Planescape Torment. There is enough content here to last you at least two playthroughs. So much care went into the little details like the fact that "Sarsaparilla" is misspelled differently every time you pick up a new bottle.


West of Loathing is a gem. It's a treat. It's all the reasons for me why videogames are worth playing.

I'm a bit torn on this game, but ultimately I have to admit it's well made.  There are hilarious moments, frustrating moments, extremely artistic moments, and annoying gameplay elements.  

The best part of this game is the comedy.  You'll have quite a few good laughs in this game. 

The art is amazing.  I can't tell you how appreciative I am of the developers opting for more creative, but less graphically intense art style.  The game and the story is utterly charming.  

What I hate is the games use of route locking. It's a trend that's becoming more and more prevalent these days. What I mean is, if you make the wrong dialog choice in this game, you can't load an earlier save, you have to miss out on something unless you restart the game from the beginning again.  Allow me to make this perfectly clear, I will never play this game a second time.  I'll probably not even finish it out of frustration because I've been locked out of too many routes. If this wasn't such a well-made game otherwise, I'd probably ask for a refund.

34719211.review:
Hey.  Yeah, I KoL'd for a long time.  Like, a really long time.  But if you're here reading reviews then you don't give a tinker's damn about that, now, do you!?

First thing to look at here is, lemme tell you what kind of people are gonna enjoy this game.  Just do some mental tick-marks in your head, then you can make the call for yourself.  That's why you read reviews, right?  This is what you want, right?  I'm not like, going insane and getting high off the smell of my own farts when I say this?  'Cause the whole point is, you don't care if *I* like the game.  You care if *you* *can* like it.

So here we go.

- Are you the kind of person who enjoys reading things?  I don't mean learning from reading--I mean the actual engagement with the rhetoric of the thing.  Like, you read it and you think half-seriously about why someone wrote it and what makes it all work, and you get this solid impression of who the writer is, almost like they're your imaginary friend.  In this game, the writer is sort of like your imaginary drinking buddy instead.  Good comic books and their narration boxes would be the best comparison, honestly, since most games are focused on accuracy with their text rather than entertainment.  Which is a bit silly when you think about it, because of this next point:
- Would you appreciate the subtle difference between a game that doesn't take itself seriously, and a game that takes itself only as seriously as it needs to?  Now, you can enjoy being the harsh critic and tearing into all the plot holes, pointing out the weaknesses and the shortcomings and where the payoff wasn't worth the investment.  Fine.  That's just being an aware, functional human being who's not liable to getting screwed at every corner.  That's not what I'm talking about.  Can you...I dunno...just let go a little bit without feeling like you're betraying that awareness?  Can you be cool about it in *both* non-temperature senses of the word?
- Do you appreciate the kind of language I'm using so far?  I'm not writing this for dummies.  You do have to have some appreciation of the English language.  Sure, I'm a bit drunk right now, but I am perfectly comfortable with talking about, for example, how this game isn't succinct and ventures into full-on loquaciousness at times, but that that serves a purpose beyond either the mechanics or the strict storyline of the game (which are both independently relevant).  It's because the meta-story matters, too.  Well, it does if you like having fun, at least.
- Did you figure out by now that maybe I drink to forget all the invasive thoughts that terrorize a fertile mind embedded in a chaotic world?  No, actually, I hope you didn't, because that would seriously justify this sort of weird and unhealthy half-acknowledged egocentrism I have going on.  That doesn't even belong in this review.  Well, maybe it does, because if you actually read further into this bullet-point anyway then it indicates an ongoing curiosity about things that don't actually matter or apply to you.  You thirst for higher knowledge.  You can't help but ponder the ineffable in search for the transcendental.  There's something out there, and you're gonna find it.  Perfect.  I like that.  That definitely applies, then, and hopefully negates my worthless moping.  Because, well, it's not just engagement with the writing but the passion for discovering GOOD writing that matters here.  And you will discover it in this game, but only if you are looking for it.
- Um...do you have a weird thing about clowns?

That should be good.  Go play this game, like comment subscribe hit the bell, then go get a life, you poor sumbich.  Your breath is getting in the way of my alcohol.  Get out of here.  Eleven out of thrifteen stars.

34667636.review:
Asymmetric's West of Loathing is closer to Fallout than Fallout 4 will ever be, letting you talk your way out of almost every single fight and providing options other than just shooting everything to death.

In some ways the setting reminds me of New Vegas but actually set during the Wild West and not some grotesque post-apocalyptic version of it. The ending cutscene is also like New Vegas, showing you how the different factions you helped or destroyed fare after the story and storylines of individual characters.

The background of the story is as follows: West of Loathing takes place shortly after an event known as the The Cows having Come Home. As a result of this, the cows have slaughtered many civilians for some unknown reason, but it could be as simple as they were fed up of being food for us humans.

Starting off as a simple man/woman living in a homestead just outside the town of Boring Springs, you're given the choice of setting some backstory for your character as well as their class. I chose to be a witty, gunslinging man who was a Snake Oiler, a sort of thief class that can heal themselves or hurt foes with snake venom harvested from the snakes in their briefcase. Yep, thats a thing.You can also be a fisticuff wielding Cowpuncher or magic using Beanslinger but I have yet to try these.

Boring Springs serves as a tutorial area, once you're done here you can never come back. It teaches you how to fight, buy and sell items, and most importantly, that you can avoid combat almost entirely with the right stats and dialogue choices. Your time here ends after you chase down one of the three unique horses or decide to go for a basic one. I chose the locoweed addicted one myself just for laughs, but the other two choices are a ghost horse and a dark horse.

One more thing to remember before leaving Boring Springs is to choose whether you want a partner to accompany you or to go solo (if you're brave enough to try). Ultimately I ended up with Susie, a sharpshooter traumatised by the recent death of her family by the arrival of the cows and so harbours an immense hatred for them. The other choices are the old man Pete, doc Alice and a secret one that is best to find out for yourself.

Upon finally leaving Boring Springs, the Wild West is yours to explore to your hearts content. After settling in to a room at the starting area of Dirtwater, the game gives you your main objective to strive for (your companion will remind you if asked, thankfully) and thats that, you can do whatever the hell you want until you feel its time to progress the story, no pressure whatsoever.

The overworld of West of Loathing and the various locations that make it up consists of settlements, mountains, mines, forts and more to search through. Then you have more unique places like the circus (complete with demon clowns) and a jelly bean museum, and my personal favourite, the Necromancer tower that can be found if you collect all the tomes and clues relating to its location.

But some of these locations, like the aforementioned Necromancer tower, can't be discovered or entered without a prerequisite item. For example, there's a cave known as the Lost Dutch Oven Mine where you need stench resistance to enter or your character will straight up refuse to go in. Another place like this is the cave place that can only be found by following tracks from another location.

A lot of items and locked doors early on will be inacessible without the required skill or stat, such as safecracking, meaning a lot of backtracking will occur towards the late game. Of course you can ignore these if you so wish but with the short travel time between locations, its not much of a bother to do so. Assuming you don't mind the random encounters on the overworld, but these can be avoided too.

The dialogue between characters is the best part of the game though, cracking jokes at the expense of other games and itself, referencing well known movies and books, or just being outright silly. Apart from the occasional repeated encounter, I never skipped the dialogue because of this.

XP levels up your stats, of course, and can be farmed infinitely at certain locations, some in particular are great for your character or companion. I myself farmed snakes for their venom which I would then sell for extra meat, and for Susie I farmed cows for a good two hours to boost her stats, resulting in her being able to one shot basically every enemy. Combat is simple enough with just the right amount of depth to it if you want to play a more challenging run.

Overall I got a good 16 hours out of West of Loathing (3-4 of those of was just farming XP), for a game that has the look of a flash browser game I didn't expect to sink this much time into it, nor did I expect to laugh so much.

Review originally posted at:  https://gamefold.co.uk/west-of-loathing-review/

34649026.review:
What I like about the game:
 -The writing is clever and hilarious. The game is full of gags, satire, and absurd logic, and it's all executed perfectly. The humor is easily this game's strongest point for me.
 -The combat system is fun, and allows for lots of creativity in how you approach battles.
 -The art style is simplistic, but pleasing to the eye.
 -You are able to decide what kind of character your protagonist is, with the choices the game gives you. Are they a stone-cold, battle-hungry killer, or do they avoid conflict whenever they have the chance? 
-There's tons of weaponry, apparel, food, and drink to choose from, to really customize your characters stats and fighting style.
-The music is epic and really enhances the experience.
-If you're stuck on a quest, there's always something else to do that's fun. 
-You can fast-travel from anywhere, even from inside buildings and caves.
-You get experience fairly quickly. If you need more experience, there's always places to grind, and battles are so enjoyable in this game that even grinding is a joy.

What I don't like about this game:
-Lockpicking and Safecracking are two very important skills that are difficult to find the skill books for if you made some mistakes in the introductory chapter, leading to a lot of frustration. In addition, the skill books are quite expensive themselves.
-...that's all I got.

I highly recommend this game if you want a good laugh, enjoy strategic and creative grid-based battles, or just feel like killing demonic cows.

34566503.review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
It's like a Loathing game, but as a proper game executable
The amazing stick figure art aesthetic remains
A brilliant and appropriately-themed soundtrack
Jam-packed with a ton of well-written humour (and a ton of puns)
Lots of quests to explore
Strongly-designed RPG elements
Support for multiple save files

[h1]Cons[/h1]
Unless you're on Hard, combat doesn't feel difficult most of the time
Fetch quests necessitate a lot of backtracking, and random encounters prolong said backtracking

[b]This game is a prime contender for my GOTY of 2017.[/b]

Like N before it, I originally started playing [url=https://www.kingdomofloathing.com/]The Kingdom of Loathing[/url], waaay back in 2006. As such, the humour and puns of KoL were an integral part of my life growing up (and also explains in part why I'm such a stickler for bad puns). I eventually quit KoL after losing millions of meat while gambling. Kids, gambling is bad, m'kay?

The announcement of West of Loathing really excited me, for multiple reasons - firstly, because it was set in the same universe as KoL; secondly, because it was a proper Steam game; thirdly, because it just looked freaking amazing. It's basically Skyrim but with a lot less real-time travelling, tons to explore, and the return of Meat as currency.

There are a lot of locations, and exploring every nook and cranny of them will reveal even more secrets elsewhere. That was part of the magic of KoL, exploring and figuring out secrets and puzzles on your own. Grab a notebook - there's a ton to remember at any one time, you'll likely forget a few things here and there, such is the magnitude of the number of things you can really do. Some achievements are rewarded for finishing some of these secrets, which span basically most of the game, giving incentive to actually chase them. You likely won't get everything on your first playthrough, but the game adequately counters that with the option for multiple save files - plus you can still continue a save file even after you've hit the end on that file.

And then, the writing. You're going to lose your sides over and over again. There is a ton of hilarious puns and well-written humour everywhere. One of the best bits about this game are the spittoon exploration moments where the disgusting details of your dank diving into the dark depths of the salty spittoons just for egregious equipment is deftly described in putrid prose. 

There's a lot of depth in combat, with a choice between 3 classes, and of 1 pardner from a total of 4 (3 have to be unlocked), each with their different traits and abilities, and a lot of skills to discover and learn, giving you freedom to spec your character. You can either casually let the game build up your character by leveling skills in a specific manner, or you can build it up yourself. You'll want this degree of freedom later on when attempting the challenge of Hard Mode in a single in-game day.

Last but not least, stupid walking. Need I say more?

[h1]When to buy[/h1]
If I'm being honest, $11 (that's ridiculous. It's not even funny.) is a freaking huge steal for what you get. I highly recommend exploring every single nook and cranny. There's so much amazing writing everywhere, and I'm pretty sure there are some bits I've missed, despite 100%ing the game.

[h1][b]9.5/10[/b][/h1]

34548433.review:
Graphic wise: The 2D b&w graphic may be a simple presentation; nontheless it is charming and sufficient enough to portary the world.

RPG & open world aspect: The map is HUGE and filled with point of interests to explore, plus all sorts of random encounters that remind me a lot about the good ol' Fallout 2. Non-linear story progession, and ample amount of meaningful options can never go wrong. Character has novel and Interesting character attributes, but combat skill may be a bit lacking. 

PLOT wise: The main quest line is about you wandering to the west. But along the way you can find different fictions, individuals, and elements. All these factors clashes and intertwines into a grand world. But all lines are thoroughly developed with clear motives, goals, and proper potential endings. It may be complex, but never disorganized. 

The game is TEXT HEAVY, in both quality and quantity. Through these words, humor shines and imagination thrives. Through these words, stick figures come to life and (AMAZINGLY) becoming distinguishable characters. Personally the text is the best part about this game.
 
Annnnd Puzzles. Tons of nontrivial puzzle to test your mind (and patience) with.

If you need one more reason to get this game, that'd be its price. 10 bucks for all what I've experienced, I'd say my money, as well as time, was well spent!

34545933.review:
West of Loathing is the gaming equivalent of a really good cheeseburger: it's not the most complicated thing in the world and the presentation might seem a little plain when it first arrives on a plate in front of you, but when you're in the right mood, man, it is filling, satisfying and juicy. Plus it comes with some fries!

I admit that analogy got away from me. Anyways.

Overall, WoL might not have the deepest mechanics, but like Psychonauts or Thomas Was Alone, the lighter gameplay is more a vehicle for superb writing and a very fulfilling sense of fun and enjoyment. WoL is not only amusing, it is also frequently and genuinely laugh out loud funny. And while a lot of the jokes are sophmoric, WoL is never a mean game. You get the sense that the creators are fans of Westerns & weird genre mashups, and aren't afraid to lampoon themselves as much as their sources of inspiration.

And boy, the game is filled to bursting with terrible puns, but the kind where you go "Man, that's terrible. I wish I had thought of that".

There are also a surprisingly large rane of options for resolving encounters and quests within the game, almost all of which have unique dialogue and story text.

While I definitely recommend West of Loathing, there are some issues. The RPG element is a little shallow. Your character will quickly outstrip your "pardner" in power and the fight mechanics seem to emphasize damage over everything else. So there are a bunch of summoning, protective and buffing skills that just dont appear very useful. And in both of my playthroughs I ended up with too many skills and not enough XP to level them all up, so I ended up relying on just two or three skills during the turn based fights.

Furthermore, WoL isn't very difficult (there is a hard mode and I didn't try it, so it may make a big difference for how the fights go). The combat is almost toothless and there's no real penalty for failing anything. On the other hand, I think the attraction is the story and jokes, so that wasn't a big deal for me.

My main complaint is that some of the quests/puzzles are a little obtuse. On my second playthrough I had to look a bunch of stuff up on a guide. I had not followed the exact sequence of questions with a NPC to trigger a big side quest, and I hadn't read the description on an item to progress one of the 3 main story quests because I had missed that I even collected the item (seriously, there are too many items). It's a little inconsistent that some quests are so maddeningly specific with how you need to complete them, while most of the others have 3 or more possible solutions, is all I'm saying. And the solution to one of the (admittedly optional) puzzles in the game apparently is from random encounters you have while wandering from place to place, and none of those encounters came up in either of my games.

But just because a game isn't perfect doesn't mean it isn't very, very good. If you like offbeat humor, a great setting, some very clever subversions of expectations and can put up with a near constant barrage of puns, you should definitely check out West of Loathing.

34545239.review:
West of Loathing is everything that made the web game Kingdom of Loathing fun at its best, minus the grinds at its worst. Great writing and amusing jokes with subtle humour in a wacky universe that is yet internally consistent. Little need for familiarity with similar titles (including Kingdom of Loathing) or gaming in general to get into it. An role-playing game that focusses on writing and player choice over numbers, forced routes or flashy animations. You actually play a role in this one.

Whilst many triple A and indie titles alike are deeper than they appear on the surface, Loathing really hits that sweet spot of surprising depth hidden beneath a whimsical clean and simple interface. The Wild West setting really gives the game a tight focus, and the character selection process is organic and layered throwing the baggage inherited from Dungeons and Dragons that plagues the genre out the window. Instead of a complex character selection screen to uhm and ahh over, Loathing opts for a Witcher 2 approach, whereby decisions you make in the early stages of the game have a lasting impact over the rest of the title. Your "pardner" is essentially part of your starting class, but instead framed as a narrative decision. The book you choose is your initial skillpoint allocation, your horse, your perks. Some seemingly minor decisions early on frame the limits of your ethical alignment. This does unfortunately bring me to one of the disappointments of the title. About 1/4 of the way into the game, these decisions start to peter out. It's not a biggie, but it was sad to see one of the most critically acclaimed elements of the game (a barrage of meaningful decisions that are contextually appropriate in effect and scope but subtle enough for the player to not skip a beat) not stick around for the long haul.

There is however one big glaring issue in the title: difficulty. In giving you so many options, including non-lethal ones, the game is essentially a joke. Nothing will set you up for even temporary failure. What's worse is that this removes the feeling of conseuence much of time. Why bother setting up solution A when solution B and C are already unlocked? Even simple stat checks are likely to be surpassed by the time you encounter them if you've spent any time exploring and enjoying the rich content on offer.

What's even more glaring is this: there is a secret hard mode, I discovered it by accident, chose it and still found the game way too easy.

I mean, this is ultimately self-defeating. Difficulty in a game like Loathing is not a matter of how skilled the player is, but on how much the game is going to expect you to tinker, experiment, explore and prepare for gateway challenges. The hard hat in particular fails in this regard because by ratcheting up the combat challenge a little, it forces you to explore non-lethal solutions or rely on consumables when you make a mistake but then turns around and removes some of the most ingenious and complex non-lethal options from you by disallowing you from switching hats, limiting your horse/pardner options, or in the case of the final set of decisions, outright robbing you of alternate options rendering the rewards from all the major story-spanning sidequests completely irrelevant!

I wholeheartedly recommend the title, and really wish for a follow-up, but I hope the developers re-assess the relationship between combat difficulty and exploration (both in-universe and mechanical) from a player perspective in order to better balance their future work. Perhaps scaling the combat difficulty to how many elements of the tutorial the player interacts with?

Expected play time: For the first playthrough, expect 8 hours if focussed on your goals and 16 hours for full exploration. Due to the number of decisions early on, and puzzles you only get one shot at, you'd need an estimated 2-3 playthroughs to exhaust all the content, leading to perhaps 30+ hours for a full completionist.

34538922.review:
I could talk about the game mechanics and the balance and whatever else, but that's besides the point. This game is a Golden Retriever puppy jumping into your lap and squirming around and licking your face - it's a friendly game that's happy and it just wants you to be happy too, and it wants you to know how much it likes you and that it hopes you're having a good time. And it's easy to like it, because you are.

This is the game equivalent of having a beer with your best friend on a nice summer's day after a rough week and she's cracking jokes to cheer you up. It's listening to an old album that you loved in high school for the first time in ages and you still remember all the words, and you know what, this is still actually pretty great.

It's warm and charming and friendly and delightful, and very, very funny. Like, ACTUALLY funny - not just a bunch of pop culture references, but humour with a distinct voice and proper jokes with a setup and payoff and a satirical bent. 

Is it a good RPG? Probably! Maybe! I mean, I think so! But that's not really the point. The question isn't whether you want a hardcore RPG experience with razor-sharp balance and deep lore, but a more basic one: do you like fun? Like, do you like having fun? Do you like enjoying yourself? Do you like laughing and great music and just having a good time? Because that's what this game is.

I seriously would recommend this game to anyone, without reservation. If I can be honest with you, random person on the Internet, I've had a rough time lately. This game has been such a warm, comforting experience that actually made me laugh and smile, and all for the price of a couple of beers. CHEAP beers even. Ten thumbs up.

34538621.review:
Wenn ihr an nem Wochenende mal nicht wisst, was ihr spielen sollt, dann empfehle ich euch West of Loathing. Das Spiel ist einfach klasse! In dem RPG-Adventure zieht man als Strichmännchenfigur durch den Wilden Westen und lernt viele interessante Orte und lustige Charaktere kennen, für die man diverse Aufgaben erledigen muss: von der Gurkenproduktion bis zur Freak Show in einem Zirkus.

Man wird in dem Spiel häufiger vor eine Wahl gestellt, was man tun möchte, z. B. mit welchem Partner man die Abenteuer bestreitet oder auch, was man mit bestimmten Gegenständen anstellen möchte. Einmal ausgewählt, gibt es häufig auch kein Zurück mehr, also aufpassen! Mir ist es das eine oder andere mal passiert, dass ich Gegenstände zerstört, gelesen oder verbraucht habe und sie mir dann bei anderen Quests gefehlt haben - das Spiel geht trotzdem weiter und man bekommt in jedem Fall eine Belohnung. Mir gefällt, dass man in dem Spiel eigene Entscheidungen treffen kann.

Die Aufgaben/Rätsel finde ich richtig toll: mal muss man Kriminelle fangen, in dem man z. B. herausfindet, unter welchem von 10 Cowboyhüten sich der Gangster verbirgt, während das Klavier im Hintergrund "Cotton Eye Joe" klimpert, mal muss man unter 20 Gräbern ein bestimmtes Grab finden, in dem man diverse Hinweise zu dem Verstorbenen richtig kombiniert. Die Quests sind sehr abwechslungsreich und es wird niemals langweilig. Es passiert auch ständig etwas Neues, wenn man durch die Gegend reist: man entdeckt neue Orte, neue Charaktere, erhält neue Aufgaben und natürlich viele Belohnungen, wie Waffen, Tränke und Rüstung - so kann man z. b. auch eine Mitra als Kopfbedeckung erhalten.

West of Loathing ist spannend, lustig und unterhaltsam: ich habe an diesem WE ca. 8 Stunden gespielt - aber mir kam es vor wie 30 Minuten. Die Zeit ging so schnell rum... Klare Kaufempfehlung für alle, die mit RPGs, dem Wilden Westen, Kühen, Goblins, Clowns, Geisterpferden, Spucknäpfen und Dynamit etwas anfangen können. 

Yee-haw!!

34471064.review:
This stick figure RPG hides a lot of fun behind its sticky facade!

Before I get to the basics of the gameplay, let me say the writing is great and it's what hooked me from start to finish.  The dialog and descriptions of objects are funny without being groan-worthy or memey.   The game for me soon became more about reading everything I could because I really enjoyed the (sometimes self aware) humor throughout the game.

For the RPG side of it, you get to choose from  melee, ranged or magic user choices; the magic user is called a beanslinger so I went with that one.  You use the world map to travel around from location to location and you'll get random encounters during your travels a lot of the time.   As you gain exp (often not from combat but through dialog or skillful use of your , well skills) you use the exp gained to level up various skills that you get at the start, or gain throughout the game from looted/found skill books.  

I did not find the combat very challenging, and that was perfectly ok because I was playing the game entirely for the story/writing by the time I realized it was easy.   There are several places in the game where you can create an infinite number of combat encounters for yourself so you can make it as easy or hard on yourself by choosing or not choosing to grind up a little.   (edit: a hard mode exists, I wasn't aware, but it's a spoilery kinda thing so search at your peril)

I played from start to finish and completed almost every side quest, afked a little, and it took me about 15 hours of playtime.  I did not hurry in any sense, I took my time and enjoyed the narratives and descriptions along the way.

Few pros: 
-excellent writing
-good humor that doesn't insult the player, not a collection of memes to be 'funny'
-plenty to do lots of side quests and interesting random encounters
-can be played almost entirely using just the mouse, you'll need the keyboard sometimes though
-appropriate music for the setting, though I admit it got a little repetitive after 15 hours
-lots of non-combat skills that affect a lot of things throughout the game, I didn't feel cheated spending exp on these skills
-for a stick figure game the animations and art really conveyed a lot, well done game creators!
-stupid walk mode!

A few cons:
-not a con for me, but the combat can be quite easy if you grind up a little exp and spend it on combat skills (EDIT: i was informed that a hard mode exists, so look into that if you want!)
-the game is in black and white until a little ways into the game where you can unlock a sorta sepia toned background, I found it to be hard on my eyes until I had the more tan colored option unlocked
-I personally found it a little difficult to remember where certain NPCs or items were again when I had to backtrack or returned to the game after a day or two break; finding this information to help me on the internet was easy but ingame could have used a little more direction, or maybe if I could have put notes on the map I could have helped myself but that wasn't an option

Recommended if you like RPGs that are witty and humorous with a lot of well written dialog and descriptions.

34436032.review:
An incredible game for the price - or indeed, at any price.  Funny, witty, clever, and with a surprisingly extensive amount of content.   Given the low price and the game's appearance, I figured it might be a long evening's work.  In fact I sunk nearly 24 hours into over several days - and despite my best efforts, I know I still didn't see all the game has to offer.

If I had to make a complaint it would be that the combat was so easy as to be basically trivial - I lost only three fights throughout the whole game, and even those I only lost because I had got so used to winning every battle in one or two turns that I no longer bothered checking enemy stats before piling in.  The game was still great fun, but it could have been even more fun (and even more of a time sink) had I had to think and strategise even a little during combat.  

There's a way of making the game harder by finding a "hard hat" which is only available at the very start and then only if you very luckily follow the exact right steps, or (more likely) Google how to find it.  That's another small gripe - I wished I had a chance of finding it on my first playthrough so as to be able to make the game more challenging.  But clearly it's only intended to be used on second or subsequent playthroughs, and I can't criticise them too much for that.  And indeed, despite how deeply I already investigated the game on my first playthrough, I may well start a second game soon.

Those are my only small niggles in what is undoubtedly a fantastic game from start the finish, and clearly the result of a huge amount of loving work.  Thoroughly enjoyable, entertaining and amusing, and at this price it must be one of the best-value new games around.

34424809.review:
West of Loathing is a delightful rpg experience with great writing and amazing darkish humor. Don't let the aesthetic fool you into thinking this is a spoof game - it's surpriginly complex, and a single run (around 100% completion) took me 12 hours.
There are multiple ways to approach the main problems, and there are plenty of secrets to discover. The game is not linear, and although it is broken into three chapters, you are never locked out of returning to previous areas (save for the tutorial area). In fact, many longer quests rely on back and forth between locations.
Has no traditional quest log, you get reminders of quests at hand but you will have to remember progress within the quest yourself for the most parts. It is possible to miss stuff entirely, or miss a different solution to a problem. Going back to old areas is often profitable due to increase in off-combat skills, like lockipicking and safecracking, which open up new opportunities for loot.
If you don't enjoy reading and usually skip any lore/book items in games, this game is probably not for you. Most of the game world is built through words, not through visuals. All the ingame writing is great, varying between genuinely funny and somewhat horrifying in tone. This includes things like item descriptions.

Heartily recommended to the fans of the rpg genre - this game is pure joy.

34418917.review:
I started playing Asymmetric's first big game, Kingdom of Loathing, nearly ten years ago. KoL features the same caliber of writing and puzzles, but it's limited in many ways to keep you playing over time- a restricted amount of playable turns per day, content exclusive to calendar holidays, that sort of stuff.

With that in mind, and having played KoL for so long, I feel confident in saying that West of Loathing is everything I ever wanted out of an Asymmetric title. Core to any "of Loathing" experience is the writing, and the writing in WoL is some of the most lovingly crafted that I've ever seen in a game. In a lot of game reviews where writing features heavily, now would be the time to invoke certain old, text-heavy titles like Planescape: Torment or the original Fallout, but they don't represent what I mean when I call the writing "lovingly crafted." There's something about West of Loathing that feels personal and warm, as if all the jokes in the writing are jokes being told to you by an old friend during a long-awaited hangout session.

The combat, let's be real, is a little rudimentary. It's Paper Mario without the fun and flashy combos. There's a sense of strategy starting out with regard to what companion joins you on your journey, and acquisition of skills ends fairly quickly, leaving you with a reliable pool of abilities to get through most any encounter- but that's about it. Each class does rely on gear entirely differently, which is at least good for replay value- and that's something this game does in fact encourage.

Go into the journey West with the expectation that you will botch a number of things the first time through. The game allows you to fail on more than one occasion- I myself was permanently banned from the circus on my first playthrough, and on that very same playthrough did irreversible damage to equipment that would have provided my party with a pretty exciting upgrade. But sometimes missing the mark can actually create even more gameplay- showing up to one of the game's later areas without a requisite item will actually unlock an entire, lengthy quest sequence you'd otherwise miss!

If I had to sum up West of Loathing in one word, I'd call it "charming." Its art style doesn't leave anything to be desired, despite the characters being represented as stick figures. The animations are lively, varied, and exceptionally smooth. It much more faithfully calls to mind imagery of being bored in class and doodling in a notebook than any number of games that have deliberately sought out that aesthetic.

If you're a thorough explorer, you'll see all that WoL has to offer in slightly shorter order than some large open-world games, but you can expect to see much greater variation from place to place than those games tend to offer. The West in West of Loathing is full of landmarks and secrets, and I didn't find even one of them to be a disappointment. There's always something for your time, which caters very nicely to treasure hunters like me.

I don't really like giving ratings out of ten, but maybe I can give WoL a letter grade. It feels like an A to me- missing the mark of an A+ due almost entirely due to how rudimentary the combat can be. Maybe the upcoming DLC can add enough content to gloss over that- or if we're really lucky, improve it. Who knows?

==========

Breakdown:

Visuals: Nice
Combat: Mediocre
Writing: Excellent
Exploration: Excellent
Jokes: Excellent

Final Grade: A

34418283.review:
West of Loathing

West of Loathing is an indie satyrical RPG focused on exploration. Choosing between 3 quirky classes you set out to the west with barely anything to your name as you explore a plethora of interesting places for hours on end.

Although the graphics may at best be charming and at worst can turn off some gamers and the combat gameplay is nothing ground breaking. The places are definitely well-designed. There is rarely any negative possibility space. You feel as though each location you visit has meaning or at least something interesti ng. This game made you want to explore the world and it's well designed levels and puzzles.

But where this game shines brightest is its narrative and story-telling. This game thrives on its ability to present its story in a satyrical and humorous way without it seeming too cheesy. It is becoming increasingly less common nowadays for games to emphasize a well-written script that this becomes a breath of fresh air from other games that have emphasized graphics and gameplay (not that there is anything wrong with those games).

Who do I recommend it to?

Anyone who is a fan of satyrical and self-referential humor will definitely have hours to burn here. 
Anyone who loves exploring interesting locations.
Anyone who wants a good laugh.
Puzzle and RPG fans.
People who love to explore a large open world.

34402047.review:
As a fan of Kingdom of Loathing, I can safely say that West of Loathing is an equally hilarious and involving game about stickfigures getting drunk and beating up goblins. In contrast with its predecessor, West of Loathing immerses you in a kinda-sorta-real (but definitely, definitely not real at all) wild west environment that is loaded with lore and references from its namesake, including food related magic, goblins with terrible grammar, and various other callbacks to KoL.

The Good:
-Excellent writing, on just about every level. West of Loathing will probably make you laugh (to tears, if you're like me) while its vivid descriptions of various happenstance apart from comedy will make you feel all sorts of things from disgust, to fear, to incredulity. 
-Easy to understand combat. An RPG though it may be, West of Loathing has at least part of a dedication to accessibility, and accomodates players of all levels. It will challenge you and punish you, but never terribly or unfairly. More over, some well placed buff stacking can often help you overcome challenges, just like in KoL. 
-Much like a classic adventure game, West of Loathing give you a great deal of freedom to do whatever you like in whatever order you'd like to do it. The way you're dropped into the world and made to "figure it out" makes for a compelling, organic experience.
-Stupid Walking.

The Less Good:
-Game lacks a truly effective quest log. It's not that I don't necessarily respect the decision to not include it, but the rate at which you can become bogged down with things to do, especially in a text based game, can become quite staggering. Without a better quest log, it gets a little mind boggling.
-The same sort of organic and non-linear gameplay used in WoL can sometimes cause you to miss out on content without ever realizing it, or locking yourself out of certain things without knowing it. (I like this about the game, personally, but I could see why others wouldn't.)

Altogether, this is a very good, and surprisingly large RPG. If you played or still play Kingdom of Loathing, don't miss this. Even if you didn't, it's a solid, well written, and extremely funny experience for only eleven dollars.

I do not like this mechanic for choosing difficulty at all however. I'd would have vastly preferred one of the following implementations:

Keep hard hat in
* Allow you to put the hard hat on at character creation.
* Tweak quests that require you to be wearing certain hats to be completed with hard hat on. If these quests were dropped for their bonuses being two strong then tweak the reward appropriately.

Remove hard hat
* Provide a difficulty selector at character creation and remove the hard hat from the game. The loss of the hat item slot is not a significant enough loss of stats to make a difference through the majority of the game.

I changed my review and I think this game is worth a pickup to anyone who enjoys a funny lightweight RPG and highly recommend you only play through with hard hat on. This does require minor spoilers to the start of the game but the change in experience is very much worth it.

34385037.review: This one is really quite good. It's an extremely silly open-ended exploration focused RPG with a great sense of humor and with many branching paths and alternate solutions. It brings to mind the best parts of certain old Sierra games like "Gold Rush", including some of the "lost forever" aspects that require the game to be replayed. But it also reminds me of Bioware-style RPGs where you explore and interact with stories and your environment in an active way. The best part is that unlike many "Bioware" style RPGs, you're not discouraged or punished for grinding if you want to. I find myself really enjoying wandering around and getting into EXTREMELY varied repeatably encounters to make my character stronger.  Finally, while the humor in this game can be a little juvenile or silly, it's NOT cynical or meanspirited in the way something like South Park is. That's rare to find these days, it's even less cynical than its parent game Kingdom of Loathing. I got a lot of smiles, laughs and relaxing times playing this game. I'll get plenty more on future replays.

34379261.review:
Let me just get this out of the way, up here in the part of the review you can see before you gotta click on a thing to see the rest of it: This game IS more than what it seems to be on the surface. It's not some off-the-rack Newgrounds Flash game. I promise.

West of Loathing is a lot of things. I guess you could consider it what you'd get if Monkey Island and Paper Mario got smashed together? Yeah, "an adventure game with RPG elements" is good to go with. It's also loaded with A+ humor. If anything, you gotta check the game out just for a good laugh.

Character creation allows for a lot of customization: You have three character classes to choose from, as well as four horses (three of which give unique gameplay perks) and a list of companions that each have their own skillsets, story relevance, and dialogue additions. You spend experience points to upgrade your stats and skills as you see fit, and there are a number of story events that also shape how your character plays and what options are available to them further along in the game.

Most of the game plays like a big adventure game puzzle. You'll build up a large inventory of items as you play, and a lot of those items can be used to solve puzzles or bypass obstacles. There's also pretty much always more than one way to resolve any confrontation or obstacle. In fact, you can even play through the entire game without getting into a single fight! Items, skills, partners, horses, and previously completed objectives can all allow you to skip fights, and while there are a couple unavoidable fights in the game, they're all in highly optional sidequests. Most of the fun in the game comes from figuring out how to avoid some of these combats!

The combat system is pretty simple, and is honestly the game's only true weak point. It can be fun if you find yourself in just the right encounter, but most of your fights will fall into exactly one of two categories: "I can kill this single enemy with one attack" or "this swarm of enemies will tear me apart."

There also puzzles. Like, a TON of them. And they're all unique. Some are easy. Some are hard. Some require outside sources to solve. If you're a puzzle nut, you'll REALLY get into some of the really deep puzzles and mysteries buried in the game.

All in all, this is a really high-quality game. There's just SO MUCH content in here, and while you CAN focus on the main objective and finish the game in a handful of hours, there's just so much side stuff to do that you can easily drop several dozen hours on a single playthrough. And even then, there's so many things that really make each playthrough different that you can play again and again and have different experiences. I can't recommend this game enough: Check it out!

34378398.review:
很久没有碰到如此让我痴迷的独立游戏了，忍不住推荐给大家。
[h1]剧情开篇:[/h1]
       我们的主角做了一个梦，梦到西部的人们生活在水深火热之中，而自己决心要背负使命前去拯救终生（此处由玩家从三个梦到的情景中选一个，其实就是选职业，大概可以归为战士，法爷和射手），在与自己的家人道别后，独自踏上了前往狂野的西部的旅途。哪知才到了第一个小镇，就开始遇到了千奇百怪的事物，一家人被发疯的奶牛屠戮而想要复仇的枪手妹子，在酒馆地下室白吃白喝的哥布林，藏有难言之隐而放弃工作的酗酒医生，整天在警局里摸鱼的警长......千方百计弄来一匹马后，才正式进入险恶的西部世界，然而还有更多未知的事物等着被发掘。
[h1]吸引人的要素:[/h1]
-类似火柴人,hidden folks 那样简洁又明快的画风
-幽默的对白(很多冷幽默)，一些很扯却吸引人探索的剧情，根据玩家自己选择而有所变化的剧情走向(可选分支有很多)，丰富的随机事件
-地图非常大，有很多区域需要自己发掘探索，隐藏要素很多
-结合了rpg要素，能感受到不同流派玩法的乐趣，拿到各式各样的装备，也能在一步步走向强大的过程中体验到游戏给玩家的成就感
-以现实的设定与魔幻元素相结合，在这险恶的西部与各种你从没想到过的敌人战斗，举些栗子[spoiler]死灵法师，骷髅军团，奶牛大军，外星势力[/spoiler]  [spoiler]很真实[/spoiler]
-很多场景与任务也是带有解谜要素的，让它不只是个单调的跑图刷任务游戏   [spoiler]很神秘[/spoiler]
[h1]一点点微小的建议:[/h1]
-作为一款rpg冒险游戏，文字自然是必不可少的元素，对于有语言障碍的玩家来说就不是那么好的的事情了，尤其是在这游戏还有大量非正式的语言形式的情况下，希望哪一天能有汉化推出，能让广大的中国玩家也能流畅体验到其中的乐趣
-不知道是不是职业选择的原因，有的怪就是非常克制，我玩的战士，见到对面全法师就是爽到，见到个射手不是你死就是我亡，队友被有的怪摸两下直接暴毙233
-手动存档？不存在的，一般经过某个区域或剧情后会自动存档，而且有的剧情是一次性的，选错了错过剧情就等着后悔了

个人不是很倾向于给游戏评分，非要我评价的话
[b]好评如潮[/b]

另外给新玩家的一些小提示:
[spoiler]不要一言不合直接干死你见到的第一只哥布林[/spoiler]
[spoiler]请忍住那不忍直视的对白，掏空所有你见到的痰盂[/spoiler]
[spoiler]不就是几个怪么，这波我很强，a了上去，打出gg[/spoiler]
[spoiler]其实这游戏没有死亡惩罚...吧，死了只会加一个爱慕安格瑞的buff，加强你的战斗力，当然超过三层好像会出事，建议还是回旅馆睡一觉先[/spoiler]
游戏还只是初体验，打的进度不是很多，大概三分之一，以后有机会再做补充吧
补充:感谢提示，突然想起来这游戏还有另一种bug级别玩法，那就是二踢脚糊脸流，由于炸药是可以通过随机事件刷出来的，理论上可以无限刷，而炸药又是20滴血固定伤害，不占用行动点数，管他多少血量，一回合全炸翻，从某种方面来说十分的简单轻松而正义。

34371412.review:
Předně musím říct, že West of Loathing nabízí vše, co byste čekali od hry s tématem divokého západu. Kolty proklatě nízko u pasu, odměny za chytání padouchů, hromada whiskey, saloon plný hudby a zábavy, krávy posedlé démony, mluvící kaktus, oživlí kostlivci, goblini, ďábelští klauni, mimozemská technologie a ehm... Dobře, trochu jsem odbočil.

Tenhle rok narážím na jeden klenot na indie scéně za druhým a po pár odehraných hodinách jsem již vytušil, že i tento titul patří mezi ně. West of Loathing nemusí zaujmout po grafické stránce, která je velmi jednoduchá. Ale o to tu ani nejde. Hlavním tahákem je totiž humor. Ten je všudypřítomný, hra si dost často dělá srandu i sama ze sebe (například v menu můžete přepnout hru do černobílého zobrazení... ve kterém je ale už od začátku... protože nenabízí ani žádné jiné barvy...). Hned v úvodu si můžete vybrat ze tří povolání a také tří koní, které osedláte: černého, duchařského nebo bláznivého, který tak vtipně koulí očima... A jelikož je tohle RPG, očekávejte hromadu úkolů s místy šíleným postupem.

Právě úkoly tu jsou naprosto parádní. Zapomeňte na AAA RPG tituly. West of Loathing se jim zdaleka vysmívá a většinu úkolů můžete vyřešit dle vašeho uvážení. Pokud narazíte například na goblina, můžete s ním bojovat, utéct nebo (pokud to umíte) si promluvit v jeho rodné řeči a pokusit se ho překecat. Je to opravdu parádní věc, když místo těžkého souboje jen mluvíte a mluvíte a nakonec přemluvíte daného nepřítele, který vám mírumilovně předá nějaký důležitý předmět.

Soubojům se samozřejmě ani zdaleka nevyhnete, přece jen jsou důležitou složkou hry. Musím pochválit animace, které jsou parádní a díky nim je ona ujetost celé hry ještě lepší. Když máte na hlavě papežský klobouk a mlátíte kostlivce obrovskou kostí, je to k popukání. Zvlášť, když si vyvoláte na pomoc obrovskou fazoli... Souboje probíhají na tahy, tzn. máte určitý počet bodů, které můžete využít. Po vás jde na řadu váš parťák a poté nepřátelé. U soubojů se musí i taktizovat, jelikož někteří nepřátelé jsou schovaní za ostatními, tudíž se k nim tak lehce nedostanete. Dalším zádrhelem jsou různé schopnosti, kdy někteří nepřátelé léčí ostatní, zatímco jiní jim trvale zlepšují atributy, díky čemuž vám každé kolo ubírají více a více životů. Během soubojů můžete taktéž využít nějaké ty předměty, které vám celý tento proces usnadní nebo se můžete krátkodobě vylepšit snězením či vypitím nějaké té dobrůtky.

Atributů tu je hromada, postupně si i čtením knih můžete odemknout další schopnosti, případně získat trvalé bonusy. Systém levelování je zpočátku mírně nepřehledný, protože tu nestoupáte po levelech, ale získáváte pouze zkušenosti. Za xp body si pak vylepšujete atributy. Rozhodně doporučuji odemykání zámků, případně sejfů, což se vždycky hodí. Také není na škodu mít vysoký level v přechytračení, protože mluvení vás dost často dostane z průšvihu.

Věcí, které tu naleznete, je hromada. Od normálního oblečení k tomu extrémně ujetému, jako například plivátko, které si nasadíte na hlavu a z nějž kapou na zem sliny. Také tu máte různé nástroje, díky kterým se můžete dostat na další místa nebo získat další předměty. Očekávejte i hádanky. Ty jsou někdy extrémně jednoduché, jindy jsou ale složitější a i já musel párkrát sáhnout po návodu.

Mohl bych pokračovat dál v recenzi a snažit se popsat každý z aspektů hry, ale myslím, že tohle je jeden z těch titulů, u kterého je nejlepší, když toho víte co nejméně. Hra je to opravdu extrémně vtipná a každý z úkolů je zajímavý. Cena je příjemně nízká, délka hry je parádní (cca 15 hodin, dost možná ale i více, záleží na vašem stylu hraní a na tom, kolik toho budete plnit). Je až s podivem, jak moc je tahle hra povedená.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ vše

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- některé úkoly si můžete nechtěně uzamknout, takže nejdou splnit

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]
[b]Mé hodnocení: 10/10[/b]

Divoký západ v černobílém provedení, s hromadou humoru a úžasnou RPG hratelností.

34366959.review:
Going to try to leave reviews of games now... and I've recently been playing a lot of West of Loathing, so!

West of Loathing is a western RPG, mostly carrying itself in the writing department. And this isn't a bad thing at all; the amount of depth and choice you're given in this game, sometimes even for the simple reward of more dialogue, is highly enoyable and I find this an incredibly easy game to recommend. I didn't know about Kingdom of Loathing prior to this game, so rest assured you don't need to have any knowledge of it prior to this game. I'm not sure how to keep going so I'll just do a pros and cons list.

PROS:

- Writing; it's humorous but provides a lot of depth to the world. Actions feel like they all have consequences and ignoring major sidequests can and will affect your ending. I loved going around to every little object just to read the text.

- Music: There aren't too too many tracks but I never got tired of them. I'll probably buy the soundtrack now that it's available, it's very enjoyable.

- Gameplay: It's simple buy fun and easy to understand. You have three base classes that determine you're main skills, and from there you're free to screw up your character as you wish. The game also has autolevels if you find that intimidating. I plan to do more playthroughs to experience other classes.

- Graphics: Yes, they're simple and resemble a newgrounds title, but I like it and think they work quite well. Every hat and weapon appears and your character which is cute.
- PRICE: This game is CHEAP. One playthrough took me about 9 hours and I plan on playing more. I would pay more for this game.


CONS:

- No real way to work with saves: the game basically runs on autosaves which I like, but if you mess up you can't turn back. I believe this is intentional, but I do wish it was slightly more forgiving for when you make mistakes in the beginning (such as putting on the hard mode hat, without any prior knowledge of the games difficulty)

- UI: The UI works for the most part, but there's some clunkiness to it. You can't tell what items have an interaction without clicking on them in your invetory and that fills up fast. I like the silly names of items, but organizing them can be a drag. Like for example, I may be looking for a quest item, but I don't know what category of item it would possibly be, and the name of the item might be like "that darn cryptic message," when my brain is thinking "I'm looking for that note that I picked up earlier". The game does attempt to provide some rudimentary ways to organize your inventory which work slightly but I definitely had some headaches looking for items. Icons for the organization aren't always clear what is what. (I know some have mentioned the lack of a quest log, but I don't mind your partner filling that role, personally)

- Graphics: I know I praised the graphics earlier, but the style does lend itself to some problems in the busier environments of the game (like Buffalo Hill). It can occasionally be hard to tell what you can interact with.

- Accessibility: I didn't see a controller option for this game, but I feel it could easily work with one. Controllers tire out my hands less, so I hope in the future this is included.

34363325.review:
This game is full of wit and humor. The animation may be simplistic, but the game is dripping with jokes, thematic glee and puns. The game auto-saves -- no loading and going back if you make a decision you don't like -- but the game moves very fast when you want it to.

Biggest pros:
1: Character is HIGHLY customizable. If you turn off auto-spending of EXP, you can level up any aspect you wish, Final Fantasy 2 style. Level individual stats, or raise your favorite skill up way early. You can't "ruin" your character and the cost to raise the neglected stats does NOT go up from leveling other things. The leveling system is wonderfully made, for finicky people like me.
2: Grinding is easy and non-mandatory. You can progress through the plot quickly if you desire, or wander aimlessly and grind, loot, and explore. Plenty of side places to visit with funny side quests, and a "Wander" button that basically means "feed me a random fight or loot please". I love it.
3: Grinding applicable to your class is available. Various areas have "spawners". If you see it say "Bigger fight" in the menu, that's a "start group battle" button. From spawning Skeletons to level your doctor friend, or spawning cow-monoliths to level your gunslinger friend, if you need a particular type of resource, chances are there's somewhere to farm it.

Note for the Developer: I watched Markiplier play this game. That is what convinced me to buy it. Just so you know, his play videos brought me to your game and gave you my business. I will be reccomending you to my friends as well. <3 I know some devs feel cheated by Let's Plays, so I wanted you to know what's WHY I bought your game. ^^

34358463.review:
For the past ten years, I've been an on-and-off-again player of the developers' first game, Kingdom of Loathing, and this shares a ton of similarities with it. If you're not familiar with KoL, it's free to play and in your browser right now, so go ahead and try it out if a funny, turn-based stick figure RPG is appealing to you and you're not ready to drop $11. 

If you liked the writing and/or gameplay in KoL this is the best of that and actually a 'real game' too. KoL can be a little frustrating to play with the daily turn limits and such, and of course there's nothing like that here.

WoL is paced well and doesn't overstay its welcome - about 10 hours long, 6 if you were just doing mainline stuff. 

A minor sticking point for me is the first 30 minutes are basically a point-and-click adventure (go here, pick up KEY_ITEM, go there, use KEY_ITEM, unlock next 'puzzle') but once you're out of that area it's got an overworld with lots of sidequests and such and it doesn't feel so constricted, and future playthroughs let you skip that.

The devs learned a lot from making KoL and you can tell from some of the design decisions about how combat works, stats, skill levels ups, etc. It's fun to play and very funny. I hope you play it!

laid-back RPG where you hangout and go on random adventures... really good game for couples / families / friends / streams... just take turns at the controls, argue over what to do, and re-tell the game's jokes and pretend you came up with them

as a game dev, it's amazing to me how much this game benefits from just renaming things, like a "dexterity" character stat is now called "moxie" and it instantly elevates this game above 50 other RPGs on steam

frankly, that just speaks to how stale and stratified video game genre traditions can be, especially in the rpg genre, and this game is all the more refreshing for bucking genre conventions so mercilessly

it also does like 100 other surprisingly subtle game design things -- the way it handles encounters, for instance, is more like a table-top rpg than a video game rpg, which works really well for this game

but let's face it, most people will be here for the non-stop puns

34343006.review:
Sometimes while you play this stickman game, you may ponder the infinite possibilities of the universe. You sit there, hands on mouse and keyboard, and wonder,"God I'm hungry. What's there to eat?"

You continue to sit there, stomach rumbling and teeth thickly coated with saliva, awaiting the next meal of the day. And you ponder. And ponder. Would it be seafood tonight? Maybe not. Would it be crackers? Something tacky? Maybe a thick chop of beef, smothered in hog oil and ranch dressing...wait what? That doesn't sound right. A meal of that magnitude requires more beef tongue, perhaps washed down in military-grade whiskey with a gin blossom chaser. If not, then a steaming hot pizza freshly plucked from the nearby grave, followed by some fine wine paired with gummy guns and a bit of ectoplasm from the ghost you had to kill at said grave because you stole his pizza. Or maybe, maybe just a big swig of ancient alien seltzer to water down a hot bowl of stewed snake with some packets of plum pudding and frisco poppy seeds floating in it, followed with two cups of fresh cactus coffee.

You stand up, unable to stand your hunger anymore. You rush to your fridge, heart and soul hopeful of what awaits you within that icy vault. You open it and those hopes sink as you realize you are dirt poor, with not an ounce of meat to your name. It's empty.

You slump and cry, you can't even afford a bottle of laudunum to quell this new found horror. You look up, wishing for a sign from God to sate your hunger.

Then, then from the corner of your eye you spot a cabinet open ajar. Your curiosity grows once more, as the infinite universe enters your mind once more. Perhaps a spare can of tuna and some soda cracker packets. Or maybe some handfuls of pork bits and a shot of snake juice to wash down those salty porky goodness. Or maybe, that elusive pickle you lost behind your couch has returned as a juice ghost pickle.

You open the cabinet, hopes renewed, only for them to be completely obliterated. There before you, lies something even greater than anything you've ever thought of. Slowly, in awe and in reverence, you open the packet before you and take it to your stove. You turn on the flame and prep your dutch oven and place the holy relics within it. You stew and stew until its ready. You pour it a bowl, careful not to spill a drop of its divine brilliance.

You prepared your spoon, and take a mouthful.

It's Indescribable. Ambrosial. Glorious.

It's as if it were born of salacious magic, of delicious wizardy.

The perfect bowl of immaculate beans. 

12/10 Would grow infinitely hungry while playing this amazing game again.

Generally speaking, I like this game. It is fun enough to keep you playing for the whole day if you are so inclined. 
However, I find that the game was artificially lengthened and could be shortened.

1. The El Vibrato stations are all over the place. It is terribly hard to remember where I have been to and cleared. This leads to a lot of backtracking. Plus I still do not see the point of them and I have found more than half. Showing them clearly on the map with a different icon once you have discovered them would have been helpful.

2. Having cleared icons on spots that you have cleared would be helpful. I forgot to get a wrench in the beginning. And by the time I figured out I needed one, I couldn't remember the spots that needed wrenching. Hence the backtracking again.

3. Some of the spots of the map don't show up until you have Wandered a few times. I have climbed up all the towers and used binoculars but they did not show up. Once again artificial lengthening.

4. When does the playthrough end exactly? Am I supposed to continue wandering infinitely with one character?

I have played some Kingdom of Loathing and I enjoyed that as well. I have nothing against side quests too. But the design in the interface leaves much to be desired.

34335493.review:
[h1]Return to Loathing with West of Loathing[/h1]

I started playing Kingdom of Loathing in 2004. This isn’t terribly unusual on its own. I started playing a LOT of games in 2004. What is terribly unusual about Kingdom of Loathing is that 13 years later, it still matters. I didn’t really start playing a game, I joined a community.

That sounds ridiculous (it’s not even funny!), but in a month I’m flying across the country to spend four days in a house with 17 people I only know because of this game. We’re going to hang out together, then go home. And we’ll do it again next year. I’m doing this instead of going to GenCon, so you can get a feeling of where this falls on a scale of ‘things Arsh wants to do with his time and money’.

So maybe that makes me the wrong person to be objective about Asymmetric’s new game West of Loathing. Or maybe it makes me the right person?

I've known about West of Loathing for forever, and I finally got to play it at PAX East this spring. I was actually surprised it wasn't more KoL-like, but was an actual walk around point and click style game with JRPG combat.It looked good, was funny, controls were tight, and the animation was excellent. I played it for maybe 10 or 15 minutes and then had to get to work, and didn't think much about it for a while.

But then, it got released. I’d been hearing DanBob talk about it constantly, and I really wanted to play it. So when it released, I bought it at work, told Steam to install it remotely, and got home that night and played for a couple of hours.

It grabbed me. It’s hilarious. It’s fun. It rewards exploration. Combat is tight, fast, and deadly. It’s got snakes. It’s got bandits. It’s got the Undead. It’s got clowns. It’s got a Necromancer. It’s got ghosts. It’s got alien technology. It’s got spittoons.

It has Stupid Walking.

I don’t really want to say too much. I don’t want to spoil any of the humor. You could decide you’ll wait for a Steam Sale and grab it for $5. To be totally honest, that’s likely what I would do with most new games. But if you buy it now, you won’t regret it.

Go get this game.

I spent $10 on a game and I've already put 20 hours into - and am willing to put another 10 to get 100% completion. That doesn't happen very often. 

Honestly, this game has more RPG depth and player choice than most major AAA titles (Looking at you, Bethesda!), a lot of puns, a lot of freedom to really putz about the world and do things your way. 

One thing to note - If you're looking for a challenge, this isn't what this game is about. The difficulty is really low, I've done the "Hard Mode in One Day" achievement on my second playthrough and had no problems except some early-game group encounters.

34330536.review: It has been a trend for a while now for AAA RPGs to double down on shiny graphics and voice acting at the expense of a player-driven story. West of Loathing is a demonstration of the errors of this kind of thinking. Don't get me wrong, shiny graphics and voice acting are both nice elements that can greatly benefit immersion in a game. Every game benefits from looking and sounding as good as possible but those things are not the main appeal of RPGs specifically. So here we have West of Loathing, a game devoid of the trappings of modern AAA RPG's. It is in fact composed of black and white stick figures who's funny dialoge is not voiced and is acompanied by music which definitely sets the mood but is hardly inspiring. Yet the game is compelling because it has it's focus on the elements that form the basic appeal of an RPG. It has a simple, yet satisfying system for bulding your characters. The addition of cool perks and skills that can be found in the world is increadibly important to the game's appeal. Unlike many other games West of Loathing isn't affraid to let you miss things which makes finding things all the sweeter, especially when an item or abillity or perk found in some random cave might unlock a new way of completing some quest. Yes, problems have multiple solutions. This is a game where choices matter. No longer is the player stuck with the ''choice'' of agreeing to do something in three mildly different ways. I should also note that West of Loathing is a comedy game. The humor hasn't exactly captivated me thus far but frankly I don't care. This game is a good RPG and that is something we have to little of these days. So if games like Fallout 4 or Dragon Age Inquisition didn't quite satisy, this game may well be for you.

34327532.review:
I think I'd rather have paid twice as much money for twice as much content, but that's a complaint not really intended for a body blow - Realistically, building the engine alone and the framework to spindle content probably took up a hefty chunk of the game's time. Also, with DLC now starting pre-production as discussed on their podcasts, that's an issue readily fixed.

The El Vib content feels forced, in desperate need of extra content like mini-bosses or landmarks more significant than just learning the languages, and memerizing all the station locations is like, emulating the third or forth worst thing about moving house in the dead of summer - where did you put everything useful, and why is it so irritating to dig through places to try and remember. 

The final big problem is not that the combat is broken - not strictly anyway - but that it is qute easy the moment you complete a little side content for stats or items, and lacks some of the hallmarks of a good western RPG: Actually challenging fights. Not all of them need to be tricky and hard, but the game is crying out for more special mechanics to add a bit of spice, and it's also crying out for more combat encounters like some of their other games (Namely Kingdom of Loathing) that feature big content zones focused around challenging and tricky combats, like Hobopolis or Dreadsylvania. Essentially, it lacks those fights like in Skyrim such as The Ebon Warrior or some of the optional dragon priests - The sort of fights that kick your ass with raw stats with a dash of counterplay that give big rewards like new items, or new subzones. I think this leads to the only neutral point in this review: The game really does feel like you're able to wander in almost anywhere, other than the gating of moving the train forward. I found myself holding my breath, my big items and all the epic gear I'd built as a cowpuncher for the strongest side boss that never really came.

The good stuff: The writing is top shelf, the game has plenty of sollutions for almost anyone, and for 11 bucks, you'll probably squeeze at least 10-20 hours of goodness from it.

8.5 stars out of 10.

34318514.review:
West of Loathing is a wacky western RPG inspired by old school RPG mechanics, hatred towards steakhouses, a love of increasingly gross details, and a bunch of guys who I'm pretty sure were drunk while making this (or crazy). 
The primary charm of the game is it's old school RPG combat and its encouragement in exploration and its mass heaps of secrets. This is a game where you will hurt inside if you don't pay attention to detail.
It may look deceiving from the screenshots, but this is a very well made game, and it was a pleasure to play it (but I'm not done yet after 11 hours *wink*). And for that, I wouldn't discourage a look on YouTube for some gameplay, Markiplier does a pretty good video about the first 30 mins (not spons). 
Sufficed to say, this game was... interesting. 
I'd sure as hell consider it some of the best $10 I've ever spent for how (sometimes annoyingly) in depth the quests are, the old school RPG combat, and the general stupidity and wackiness this game bleeds. I have never thought so highly of spitoons in my life (and Markiplier would know why).

https://youtu.be/TsFU6LzI6jQ

What can I say about West of Loathing? Stick figures, dad jokes, engaging gameplay, and humor oozing out of every aspect of the game, it is an absolute jjoy to play. With 3 playable classes, decisions that encourage player choice, this game does not limit you to an on-rails experience. 34300989.review:
I remember listening to a podcast this developer did (Video Games Hot Dog, it's really neat) while this game was in development, and they (jokingly, maybe?) referred to it as Skyrim with stick figures. While this is a pretty accurate comparison, it is also a lot more than that.

If you've ever played Kingdom of Loathing (it's free, dork) than you have a good idea what to expect. Well, minus the multiplayer anyway. Jick's hand drawn art comprise the graphics, Hotstuff put some ridiculously over the top puzzles in here, and Riff wrote a lot of corny yet effective jokes. 

If you don't know what Loathing is all a bout, this is a turn-based western themed rpg, with a large helping of humor. You have your standard Fighter / Mage / Thief gameplay, but they aren't called what you expect. Stats and items also go out of their way to not be cookie cutter rpg tropes.

The game is very player friendly, and greatly respects your time. You can speed up combat so it plays out super fast, you don't waste a turn when you use items, health is restored after each fight, and the vast majority of fights can be bypassed with skill checks without losing out on the rewards.

This can all make the combat feel pretty easy, but combat difficulty isn't what this series is about and it probably isn't why you are here. The puzzles you will come across range from simple ones you will trip over as you go, to super difficult obscure ones that you might not even notice.

I don't want to talk about the plot for risk of spoilers, but I was laughing right from the start. 

Also, I shoveled horse dookie for experience and dug around in spittoons for loot while the game scolded me for doing so. Money well spent.

The West of Loathing is based on the A+ humour of the universe of browser PHP game Kingdom of Loathing. The charm is the same, and on top of that West comes in a much easier to consume package.

The animation, active controls, and sound give this adventure RPG much more watchable presentation, not having to check in daily is all well and good, the combat isn't too bad, you can do all the min-maxing you want. It has a lot of tongue in cheek stuff including some interface muddling, but doesn't get pretentious about it and use it to scare and or induce questioning of existitude. It knows what it is and where it stands.

It's also an RPG that ends in like 6 hours. Half that if you cut the chaff and get straight from beginning to end. So if you don't like long slogs boy are you in luck. If you hate anti-climaxes boy are you NOT in luck. The thing I thought unimportant turned out the be the main plot, and all the ominous evil stuff was just on the side. Some nifty puzzles, though.

Also props for all the quality of life stuff here and there, options for speed and some convenience for surmounting ingame mechanics. They don't hornswoggle you around unless they intend to.

34270852.review:
Five good reasons to buy West of Loathing: 

1) Sophisticated, earnest writing. The game knows when to be funny and when not to be. And while toilet-humor abounds (both literally and figuratively), the jokes are never truly idiotic, nor meanspirited. 

2) Freedom of choice. Do you want to solve the puzzle or bypass it entirely? Do you want to engage in every subquest or barrel through to the ending? Do you want to kill every enemy you see or attempt a pacifist run? Anything is possible, although certain choices do have meaningful consequences. Different kinds of people will enjoy the game in many different ways and on many different levels.

3) Charming music, art and animation. And there's a continual stream of new stuff to see from beginning to end.

4) Cheap price. There's at least $20 worth of content in here.

5) Trustworthy developers. This is a small indie company with ~15 years of experience that actively engages with their playerbase. They want to generate DLC and make new games. Good sales will directly effect their ability to do so. If you, the consumer, don't actively support them, then no one else will.
