34269210.review:
West of Loathing is a great game, worth much more than the $11 price point suggests. It is funny, entertaining, and (most importantly) fun to play. There are jokes at multiple levels, threads that pop up for a giggle, then disappear only to pop up an hour later and build on what they've started. There are easy puzzles and very tricky puzzles, even some puzzles that are intended for the community to solve by working together over months.
I've played through the main storyline and "won" but it will be a very long time before I 100% this wonderful game. There are just so many little gems tucked away in the corners waiting to be found.

As far as fun to play goes, even if you are not into the jokes and wordplay and intentionally goofy art style, West of Loathing still has you covered. The devs took the tired old tropes of the RPG genre and threw in a whole bunch of nice features on top of them. You have skills and stat points and XP, but if you don't want to micromanage that, the game can take care of it for you. Love collecting every single thing not nailed down and sticking it in your backpack? Infinite inventory with built in sorting and categorization to make dealing with it easier. Tired of deciding whether to hoard your potions or heal up before a big fight? You start every combat with full HP and MP (the game calls them action points). Don't like wandering a zone to wait for random encounters to strike so you can grind up? There are many places where infinite monsters spawn so you just go up to the thing and click "fight" and you're in combat. 

The only thing I don't quite get is how they are only charging $11 for it, when i's worth so much more. It's ridiculous. It's not even funny.

34269172.review:
This is an exceptional thing.

If you like your RPGs old-school and Zork-flavored, this is the game for you. If you're on the fence about either of those things, there's still a lot here to like.

For a parody western based on a parody fantasy turn-based, tick-based, pun-based MMO, West of Loathing is a startlingly good. It's not just satisfying as an RPG, it's wonderfully written, cleverly designed, and a really satisfying counterpart to its MMO source game. Referential humor, absurdism, and a weirdly deep understanding of both what makes a good western *and* the real-world history of the California area at the time are all on display here, and those are great on their own, but WoL is also not afraid to delve into some fairly strong horror and some of its puzzles and subplot threads are so convoluted that the community is still exploring it for bits of hidden content.

Prior knowledge of the MMO is not required to play (and thank goodness, because playing through the MMO is something of a chore), but its lore *does* enrich WoL in a big way. In fact, WoL is a much less silly story than KoL, and it's got quite a bit of actual pathos.

I've found myself caring about the characters that I meet in a way that simply does not happen in most parody games, and I'd recommend WoL on the strength of that alone.

BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE

Three detailed classes, each with unique playstyles and ways of interacting with the world. 

A whole host of unlockable and levelable skills, hidden perks, item-based abilities, and other crunchy, mechanical goodness that influences both combat, conversations, and interactive points on the map.

Tactical combat against a wide range of foes. While not very mechanically satisfying, it doesn't drag and it's usually backed by good writing at both ends.

A fairly massive world map, utterly crammed with fully explorable locations. It feels and looks like a Fallout-style world map, but what really stands out is the sheer diversity of random encounters that have been coded into the game. I've seen the same combat twice...a couple of times. And there's a short random encounter almost every time you take a trip.

Basically, this game is a labor of love.

If you don't like doing a lot of reading, if you dislike RPGs, or if you have a burning need to be a completionist, this might not be the best experience for you. Otherwise, $10 is perfectly reasonable for this indie gem.

34267053.review:
I have no sense of humor whatsoever due to Asbergers and I still like this game. Even if I don't/can't understand 95% of the jokes and have never played Kingdom of Loathing, (it's prequal/spinoff/whatever), it was still a good RPG on it's own. It has puzzles, some of which are the standard simple RPG fare, and some of which require a lot more time, effort, and brainpower to figure out. It has a story that makes sense in the world of the game, and for the most part, what you need to do to progress is fairly simple.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
This is a standard turn based RPG and the combat system doesn't do anything new. Not that it needs to. If you've ever played any turn based RPG you'll recognise this system. Combat is very simple. The characters with the highest speed stat go first, basic attacks are free, and the rest of your skills require action points, of which you have a limited number per fight, and action points reset every fight. 

Interacting with things is easy and basically involves running up to whatever object you want to interact with and press 'e'. Sometimes you might need to go into your inventory and use an object. The actual interaction part is very easy. The actual steps you might need to take to complete some quests in a certain way is more difficult, but that's part of the fun.

Choices exist. There are multiple ways to finish quests, multiple ways to build a character (even if it's the same class), and many other choices besides. The game is directly influenced by how you do quests and which people you help. It is entirely possible to be locked out of some choices/quests if you kill everyone you see as a potential threat immediately. It is also possible and likely that you'll wind up selling off a load of junk and someone will ask for some of it later (not that you can't get more of it, but still.)

[b]What this game is not:[/b]
An exploration game where you go out into a monochrome 2d world and find things. There are set locations on your map, you go there and that area is rendered for you. There are random events as you travel between locations, but they don't have an actual area for your character to walk around in and find secret passages or anything. There are 'secrets' but they are usually fairly obvious from a visual standpoint, even if your character doesn't immediately have the skills needed to get into that area.

Forgiving in terms of optional puzzles. You can complete the main game and most quest chains in towns no matter what. You may not do it as cleanly or optimally as you'd like, but you can do it. It is, however, very possible to screw up several puzzles or very off-the track side quests (either by doing the puzzles incorrectly or by killing people you need), in such a way that you can't complete the puzzle or can't get the best ending for a quest. For example, minor spoiler in the first half hour [spoiler]The goblin that the bartender in the prologue asks you to kill can be a companion... as long as you don't kill him and actually manage to find out how to communicate with him, which most people aren't likely to do on their first try/playthrough[/spoiler]

34261109.review:
As a Kingdom of Loathing fan and as a guy who bought this game just yesterday, I really can't endorse it enough to communicate what a pleasant and fun experience it is to play. 

West of Loathing is made of fun, inoffensive jokes that lean heavily on absurdity and don't give you that gross feeling you sometimes get when you catch yourself laughing at a dead baby joke, or a picture of Donald Trump's head photoshopped onto a Cheezit. Every joke is a strong 8/10 that surprises you just enough to get a chuckle, but this is where the importance of that sort of implementation of humor comes in. 

There are a lot of jokes. A lot. 

As in, every item description. Every skill description. Almost every interactable, and the game has a bunch of those. 

Every conversation is dripping with humorous dialogue, often jumping in an even rhythm between droll observations and wordplay ("Your horses are flying out the door? I'm glad business is going well!", to which someone responds, "No, like they're running out of the door every day. I haven't had a sale in weeks."), to sudden backwards steps in logic that force anywhere between a chuckle and a guffaw of laughter out of you based upon how surprised you are (That same man then gives you a bag of homing oats to feed his horses, which are special pigeon-infused oats that will compel them to go home). 

The combat's a bit eeeeehhhhhh but it's very inoffensive at worst, and it's quick and very rarely difficult at all. It's meant to be there to facilitate gameplay, not waste your time. A lot of the animations are absolute gold as well - the Rattlesnake in Thousand Snakes Gulch, instead of slithering, bounces up and down like a pogo stick on its way to attack you. 

Plus, dude, there's this skill called Stupid Walking, and it just replaces your walk cycle with one of a dozen different animations that range from swimming on the ground, to step-dancing, to tucking yourself into a ball and rolling across the ground. Each one of those animations even has its own sound effects, because the joke works so much better when you hear the translation from face-sliding to Frankenstein-walking happen. 

KoL has an absolutely charming and timeless style of humor that applies to pretty much everyone, and the same is true of WoL. However, this humor all belies something else as well: 

West of Loathing is a fantastic point n' click style, "Items are your friends and the only way to solve this quest chain" adventure game as well. Almost every quest has either multiple solutions or hidden paths involved; half of the best loot and skills in the game come from interacting with the environment, not leveling up or solving a quest chain. 

In the first area alone, you can miss two party members, four pretty decent items, three horses, three snake skins, a magic ring, and a turnip by either taking hasty solutions to problems or skipping environmental interaction. This game wants you to do everything, and is very open to the notion that you in-fact should if you want the full experience. 

The game doesn't punish you for playing like a jackass, and it doesn't rely upon specific builds or character classes to engage in a lot of the environmental gameplay (The Foragin', Dickerin', and Lockpickin' skills, each of which open up specific environmental interactions and dialogue choices, are chosen outside of your class). 

It's a fun, open game that doesn't lose its charm no matter how much of it you play. It's not Skyrim, it won't go on for 400 hours of mildly-satisfying gameplay - but the 60 or so hours you can get out of it, you'll probably enjoy a lot more. 

So yeah, West of Loathing. I strongly endorse it. For ten bucks, it's a dramatically better decision than you'd expect.﻿

34257947.review:
[i]Total disclaimer: I haven't finished the game yet. But honestly, it's found a tone and stuck to it and I don't suspect it will change very much so I feel comfortable writing this. [/i]

So, about 1000 internet years ago, a browser game called Kingdom of Loathing happened. Basically, it was the game I'd probably come up with if you told me to make an RPG - a big vehicle to house billions of stupid puns and goofs, without nearly as much thought given to gameplay or art or etc.

West of Loathing is basically the same thing.

You'll probably start off looking at the store page, and assume that it's gotten mostly positive reviews as a joke. The screenshots make it look rudimentary in design and visual style. And, certainly, this game takes a certain kind of person to really enjoy. If, for example, you can't derive massive amounts of enjoyment from the fact that Necromancy is referred to in-game as "Nex-Mex", this probably isn't your bag.

Me? I chuckled again just THINKING about that. So, you probably know by now I'm going to recommend this.

But here's the gist of the game anyway. It's a wild-west RPG that works ideas from the American Southwest into the framework of a more traditional turn-based game. It actually reminds me a bit of Fallout in terms of its execution - heavily skills and consumables-focused. It's surprisingly deep for a game that's effectively a joke storage facility. I recommend speeding up the combat (there's an option for it), because the animations do get tiresome.

There is a suprisingly large amount of content in the game - I'd estimate at least 10 hours' worth based on my current progress. I wouldn't be shocked if this game features the largest number of jokes in a game to date, and somehow most of them land. The visual style is much more richly detailed than it first appears - everything is crudely hand-drawn, but the environments have layers, and the game actually looks pretty good.

The sound design is similarly surprisingly good. I was shocked to find this game has directional audio AT ALL - yet it does.

Overall, West of Loathing is full of little surprises. For $11 (clever in-joke there), you really can't go wrong. It's a solid 10+ hours of amusing quests.

And also I fed my horse spooky oats, for she is a ghost, and ghosts only eat spooky food.

34250416.review: West of Loathing takes great roots in its style, thankfully similar to the web browser game Kingdom of Loathing. KoL was a free to play game working off of donations, meaning it could use licensed material to a degree. Sadly most of those pop culture references wont be found here, what will be found is the most meta-meta game you choose to put your heart into. I cant promise you you would get 100 hours out of this game, or even 50 hours, as the content only goes as far as you wish to explore every last inch of the map and check for easter eggs. The rpg elements are fun and classes exactly similar to the 2016 challenge paths, If you were a fan of KoL and wish to extend the adventure, 11 dollars is quite reasonable for what you receive.

34246260.review:
Wow. Wow wow wow. Thank you so much asymetric. You've brought back so many fond memories of when I was in middle school, playing Kingdom of Loathing with my younger brothers at the library. I'm done with college now, and I don't have much time these days for games, however, I found my hours flying by playing West of Loathing. The game is absolutely fantastic - despite the bugs that have been already addressed with the v1.01 patch, coming out just days after the launch - a testament to the continued quality of work you've been truly working so hard at for years.
A couple suggestions to further improve this already 10/10 game:
1) Create another Muscle, Mysticality, and Moxie character, 2 per type, as you have in Kingdom of Loathing with the Turtle Tamer, Seal Clubber, Disco Bandit, Accordian Thief, Pastamancer, etc.
2) Expand a tad bit on the included features: make completing sidequests relevent for all the right reasons! Include monster books for monster identification, hidden collectibles, and a journal system.
3) When wandering, possibly include random events that allow you to explore some of the landscape outside of the regular visitable locations.

Those are just a few suggestions! I don't want to make this long winded, because honestly, the team has done such a fantastic job on the game already, and I look forward to the many more hours I plan on putting in to play this.

34246245.review:
Currently at 5.6 hours in, and deliberately trying to make sure I see at absolutely much as I can at each phase before moving on, everything about this game is fantastic. The jokes are great, the mechanics are great, the theming is great, the soundtrack is frigging perfect. I've never laughed out loud at my screen more times than I have with this game, and there's still a whole half of the map I haven't even touched yet, to say nothing of all the jokes hidden behind skill choices I didn't make. I've also never wanted to go back and play through a game again with different choices, but I'm already making notes of which skills I ended up losing out on content due to not having, to make sure the next time through maximizes what else I can see.

Worth twice the price and more, and an absolute steal at 11 bucks. Buy this game.

34240691.review:
This game is awesome. 

If you were/are a fan of KoL then chances are you will love this game.

The humor is the same, with all the silliness and randomness that made KoL so entertaining.
I've only played for about three hours and I can't even count the amount of times that I've laughed out loud.

Combat is a little boring, but the quests and items are interesting and have not failed to hold my attention at any moment. There also isn't a quest journal so I would recommend taking notes, there are a lot of areas that are inaccessible when you first discover them, but open up once you find that certain item or when you get the needed perk. 

Also the dialogue in this game is a little weird. For the most part you are going to want to talk to people a few times before you leave them for good. A conversation will seem like it's over, your character will say goodbye, and you may think that you have gone as far as you can go with an NPC, but it isn't. Try talking to them again and you will often see that there is a dialogue cue that popped up after you have left. 

I have minor gripes with this game, but they remain at that. Minor. Overall this game is very enjoyable, if you enjoyed your time in the KoL then you will 100% enjoy this game as well.

34225709.review:
Solid.

This game is *all* about the humor. First and foremost you should peek at some screenshots on the Steam page, maybe poke around Kingdom of Loathing's website, that sorta thing.. If you get a few chuckles from that then you'll probably enjoy the game. Otherwise? You likely won't, period.

The game is vastly about its humor, writing, and silliness/wittiness. The RPG aspect is cute, and the stats and items and combat all add a bit of depth to it, but it feels a smidge.. fast and loose? Enemy health and such varies  kinda suddenly, some of the items and stats and all aren't too logical and intuitive, but frankly none of it is a show stopper nor makes much of a difference.. because the game is vastly about its writing, aesthetic, and being amused as you meander your way through it.

I personally find it fairly amusing, however it's not just the one-off snarky jokes or silly remarks themselves, but moreso the overall voice of it, the sheer consistency of it is as amusing as any one particular joke, gag, pun, or what have you. It's constant, and not in a way that's annoying, they keep finding clever little ways to usurp language or expectations to create another iteration or twist on the same tired, but irresistably snort-worthy, gag.

34220327.review:
West of Loathing is fun, funny, big and clever. Its focus on letting players pick the solution to a problem they want is particularly endearing—many encounters can be resolved peacefully, puzzles can be circumvented and there are secrets to discover everywhere.

The tone of the game is somewhat more serious than that of Kingdom of Loathing. While everything is still a joke in some way, the world building is consistent and characters have serious motivations. Unfortunately, the story just sort of ends suddenly, in an abrupt enough manner that I spent the better part of an evening exploring the post-game wondering if I had missed something. 

I hope the game sells well enough to justify further development. An expansion would be nice, and a New Game+ mode would fit the game very well.

34216841.review:
I played Kingdom of Loathing years ago, but dropped when the game became overwhelming (after they implemented the sea and a couple of clan dungeons).
West of Loathing is everything I loved about KoL, the humour, the bizarre setting that can shift from subtle to grotesque in the same minute, and simple gameplay mechanics that can be fine-tuned and made complex at will. It also includes the most terrifying ghosts that have ever haunted a video game.

If you never played KoL but like quality writing, this is a very clean and addictive RPG. It's just short enough (around 8 hours, but can go longer or much shorter if you don't dive in the massive side-content) and has good re-playability (the three classes play nothing alike, and the choice of partners change the game significantly). Also has a hard mode that require a good understanding of the more intricate mechanics. Warmly recommended.

You'd think a relatively basic and simple RPG thats mostly fun because it's charming and funny would wear out its welcome quickly. Thankfully this has the consistency, variety and taste to continuinally feel densely and refreshingly entertaining (or, occasionally, revoltingly horrifying). Some quests have alternate, usually funnier ways to solve them beyond "just kill everyone", there's skill checks and stats and weird abilities, there's rpg combat and puzzles, yet ultimately that's all more intended to be cohesive glue and base for the humor instead of challenging roadblocks or deep systems to theorycraft around. It's "just" serviceable, by design. Luckily the thing it serves is one of my favorite experiences this year.

A lot of the qualities of this come from its writing, so if you enjoy formats like ClickVentures you'll feel right at home. If you can't or don't like reading you probably won't even have made it this far into my review so hi cool readers, let's all laugh at those lazy goblins together, high five!

34208317.review:
If you...
[list]
    [*]Posess a sense of humor
    [*]Enjoy RPGs
    [*]Can read
[/list]
...you really should just buy this game.

It may look simple initially, but there's plenty of depth here. The writing is great, the quests are fulfilling, the puzzles are enjoyable without being frustrating, and the plot is well-developed (though, yes, rather weird). The art and animation style is also of higher quality than I expected from the screenshots. The lighting in caves, for example, is particularly cool and adds a bit of clever realism. There are plenty of non-obvious things to interact with and enjoy. I found that I never tire of finding another little clever addition to the game.

One thing: You have to enjoy (or at least feel comfortable with) reading a lot of text. So much of the richness of the game comes down to if the player is paying attention to the dialog and descriptions. If you don't actively read or if you just skim, you can miss important hints for quests and jokes that might be built upon later.

There are a few significant references here and there to jokes you find in KoL (for example, certain numbers are often used) which made me feel connected to this game in a way I may not otherwise have been had I not been such a devout KoL player from 2004-2010. I'd expect that someone unfamiliar with KoL would not notice nor be any worse off, however.

The only complaint I have is that I really really want to be able to change how the keyboard controls are set up. I do not find it possible (or comfortable) to use only the keyboard, which I would much prefer.

Overall, this game is entertaining as hell and I find myself literally laughing aloud. I think it does a great job of capturing and keeping the interest of the player. The price is quite reasonable and it surpassed all my expectations. A+.

34197440.review:
West of Loathing is a lovely game. Is that weird to say about a game? It's just lovely. Everything about Loathing is completely charming! 

I was a beanwizard cowpoke travelling with a world-weary whiskey-swilling sawbones who had a vendetta against skeletons. Riding together on my pale horse (an actual spooky ghost) we set off to rid the world of a dread necromancer and also uncover the mysteries of an ancient alien civilization lurking in the deepest parts of the frontier.  But that's just another day in the wild west.

West of Loathing is a comedic RPG that starts cracking jokes right from character creation and never lets up. It riffs on its weird west fantasy setting relentlessly, presenting you with beanslinging wizards alongside guntotin' outlaws. It's absolutely dense with jokes, puns, and clever writing.

That's not to say that it's a joke game: as an RPG, it's robust in terms of character development and player choice, especially if you elect to manually spend XP. Nearly every situation has multiple dialogue choices and solutions based on your character stats, skills, and items at hand, and two players might have wildly differing experiences as a result. It draws inspiration from 90's cRPG design, yet Loathing feels inviting and approachable to nearly anyone. The turn-based combat is not terribly challenging outside of a few key fights, but feels meaty enough as connective tissue in between exploration and walking up to every object to read new jokes. (There is a hard mode, but I haven't tried it.)

It's so easy to write off a game like this based on looks alone. "Stick-figure RPG" conjures images of amateurish flash games from the early 2000's, but Loathing is anything but amateurish. The hand-drawn art is joyous, not crude, and communicates so much character, especially in motion. About ten seconds into the game you can unlock a menu option that makes you walk silly. This would've been a one-off joke except they crammed in about two dozen incredibly silly walk cycles (including context-sensitive ones!) that I kept it on the whole game, just admiring the sheer goofmanship involved.

My initial playthrough clocked in at about 9 hours, with most (but not all!) of the side content completed, and I'm already starting another character to see the things I missed. Side quests are at the heart of Loathing. The game world branches out in scope like a Bethesda game might. The main quest is fairly barebones, serving to gate the three sections of the overworld, and making a beeline for it would lead you to miss so much of the clever writing and wonderful characters that make the game worthwhile.

Besides the standard combat scenarios, there's also some surprisingly cerebral puzzles: these are going to be hit or miss depending on the player, but be prepared to take notes on some of the more fiendish ones. Or, being side content, they are entirely skippable if you'd rather not engage with them.

Overall, West of Loathing is a very funny game with solid RPG bones that has both depth and accessibility. The combat may be the weaker part of the game, but is perfectly serviceable and resolves quickly. Branching choices and hidden content mean that there's a good amount of replay value too.

I don't think a minute passed without Loathing putting at least a smile on my face, never mind all the genuine laughs I had. West of Loathing is a real gem, relentlessly goofy yet clever, and always ready to charm. Lovely.

34195769.review:
[b][i]West of Loathing[/i] is a great RPG adventure with fantastic humor and remarkable attention to detail.[/b] As far as indie RPGs go, it checks all the right boxes if you are interested in a standard RPG romp. The whole thing is fun. Even the menus. 

[b]The only thing I'd like to put out there is the idea that if you take an RPG game and strip it down to it's most basic form with all the elements exposed - you will find it is simply a series of fetch quests.[/b] Now some games hide this grind exceptionally well, and others, well, don't. How well the layers of complexity cover this basic element generally define the fun, help with immersion, and keep you coming back for more. [b][i]West of Loathing[/i] is pretty 'meh' about hiding the fetch quest mechanic.[/b] This is really the only fault I find with this title, although you must understand that it is a big one. When I play in anything less than short bursts, it totally gets real spam clicky because I'm just rushing around from point A to B. Yes, all RPGs are like this, but it is a fundamental weakness in the genre. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Great humor
+Major props for getting around having to hire some big expensive artist; the art here is quirky, charming, and works well and could be done by someone who has a little bit of skill
+Music is really fitting
+Good amount of content
+Everything is fun; even the menus

[b]Cons:[/b]
-The fetch quest is strong in this one
-Could use a 'dark' mode (yes I use Nostalgia option); the bright white on a large television is too much 

[b]Yeah, this one is really fun.[/b] Worth full price.

34183515.review:
West of Loathing has the absurd humor that Kingdoms of Loathing was quite well known for. It's funny, and it does it well. The RPG side of the game is a little bit lacking, and you will soon find yourself completely destroying any competition without much effort at all. Once you are 3 or 4 hours into the game, it's nearly impossible to die unless you do some stupid stuff.

The game has a paper-thin overarching plot that is pretty much second to the main activity of the game: completing side quests. When you play this game, you will essentially be on a never ending chain of side quests. You get one side quests that requires you to go to a new place, and the person there sends you on another side quest that you have to do in order to complete the original side quest. Repeat this until you are on 14 different side quests at any point during the game.

Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game, and it's a funny game. For the first few hours. It just lacks any staying power.

I wish I could finish this game, but unfortunately if I have to read another novel before a guy just sends me to beat up some bandits again, I'm gonna have to blow my brains out.

34169603.review:
[i]West of Loathing[/i] is a hilarious indie adventure/RPG that's somehow better at doing the whole 'old-school RPG' shtick than Obsidian's current games.

Seriously. It's probably obvious at first glance that [i]West of Loathing[/i] is comedy—and it is, indeed, absolutely hilarious. It's worth picking up just for the tone, ridiculous items, ability to do bean magic, choose to ride a crazy horse for the 'insensitive' achievement, explore the depths of spitoons (it's just as bad as it sounds, so WoL doubles as a horror game), receive XP-charged air from you brother, get a separate perk for hurting yourself on cacti too many times... and, most luxuriously of all, change the game's font to Arial.

However, what is less obvious is how good of an RPG WoL actually is. It's not very challenging—but it adheres to the idea that an RPG game is first and foremost about finding different approaches to various problems, not just fighting monsters. So you can, for example, make it harder... you just need to [i]find[/i] the item that adds challenge first. Want to make a good fortune in the West? Good luck with that—you'll have to really honestly [i]search[/i] for it, no hand-holding. Seems like something is stirring, and those are the bones of dead people? Once again, it's up to you to look for the Necromancer raising them. Or not.

For a 2D black-and-while stick-figure parody WoL is surprisingly open-ended. It has cryptography puzzles to be solved and musicians to be found in unexpected places. Most important conundrums can be approached in a number of ways, while others become secrets for you to unveil over the course of the playthrough... or several ones?

So yes, [i]West of Loathing[/i] is a perfect blend of adventure and RPG, that feels robust despite being limited in scope. You never know which seemingly random action will grant you a perk or help out.

And if nothing else, it's worth playing for the fact that most needles in the game are found in haystacks.

34169434.review:
If you have no familiarity with the Kingdom of Loathing (KoL) or Asymmetric - fear not! This game is loaded with clever writing, fun to experience content, and easy to pick up gameplay. The tutorial didn't really feel like one, but gave me all the information, motivation, and tools I needed to dive in - and the tutorial had plenty of content to whet my appetite before sinking my teeth into the fairly open world and main storylines. As an RPG, the three main classes and skilll systems seem really expansive but not overwhelming, and has a simple turn based combat engine (with layers of mechanics like elements, close and long ranged weapons, skills, etc.) So far, combat hasn't felt repetitive or needlessly aimed at making you grind - and the challenge can be amped up early in the game, if you're up for it. 
The highly entertaining written narrative and dialogue, fused with the simple quirky art design, creates an experience that is memorable and stands out compared to so many games available these days. Stick figures in hats dancing and drinking couldn't look better. Everything seems assembled with care and placed into the game with love, and the details don't distract you.

I implore you to check this out if you:
Are a fan of classic RPG adventures.
Can appreciate aesthetics and graphics in a game besides what you'd normally see in cinematic heavy AAA titles.
Enjoy a game with clever writing (not just notes scattered about for narrative purposes)
Want to save the West from the ever rising cow-demon threat.

What can I say - if you know anything about Kingdom of Loathing, you'll enjoy this game. 
Whether your KoL experiences were a brief time playing with it years ago, playing on and off like myself for 10+ years, or being a complete veteran or noob to Asymmetric's unassuming yet highly engaging and deep browser game, West of Loathing draws on KoL's charm and strengths and is amplified in a special way as a standalone experience.

34162928.review:
This game is delightful. In terms of basic structure it's similar to most RPGs where you have a main quest and sidequests that you're going on and along the way you're collecting stats, new equiptment, meeting NPCs, visiting towns, etc. 

[h1]First the Pros[/h1]
The best part of the game is definitely the creativity, humor and sense of discovery -- because of the simplicity of the graphics and just the style of the game, it allows for a lot more varied combinations of stuff and situations. Unlike most RPGs, it doesn't really have a part where you're just grinding away mindlessly; the story's constantly moving forward and there's constantly new locations to be discovered (that's the beauty of simple graphics!).

Also, don't let the stick figures fool you -- this is a very thought out and carefully made game. It's well-balanced in terms of item drops, difficulty progression, fun plotlines and stories, variations to enhance replayability, etc. Each aspect of it feels very intentional. For item drops, for example, I find that in a lot of RPGs it's either too flukey in terms of getting good items (to the point where there's too muck luck involved) or more frequently most of the junk you collect doesn't matter except after a boss battle. This game is not like that at all, you're constantly getting different stuff in the way thay makes sense. There's no part of it that feels like an afterthought.

Plus, people familiar with the genre will notice that they've taken the time to consider the little things to take annoyances out of the game -- there's no inventory management (unlimited inventory) and you don't spend time trudging around (you can always go straight back the main map and there's no long stretches of walking -- I personally hate watching my character walk around in games so I love when developers have taken that into consideration). I love, love, love that you can speed up the combat animation to 300% under the options. I love games that don't waste my time.

This game looks casual, but there's so many decisions in the design of it that were clearly very intentional and thoughtful.

[h1]A Few (Negligible) Cons[/h1]
The only downside I could find was that there's so much going on especially once you get further into the game - locations, quests, things to go back to - that it's a little hard to keep track of. I hardly think that's a big knock against this. Beyond that, it's up to you to decide if you're OK with the graphics -- I loved Kingdom of Loathing back in the day so I knew what I was getting into. 

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
For most seasoned RPG players, this game won't be too difficult. As long as you're careful, you can avoid a lot of the stuff that'll kill you outright, plus there's no permadeath (you just wake up and it's a new day) so you might get slowed down but it's not going to feel like you can't progress. It's heavy on puzzles which, depending on what you're into, may be a plus or minus for you. 

That said, there's also a hidden Hardcore Mode ([spoiler]it's a hat, actually, and you can find it during the prologue, but it affects a lot more than just what you can wear on your head[/spoiler]) where the game gets significantly more difficult in terms of combat. As far as I could tell, the puzzles stay the same. So, if you're not into the puzzles and want a harder game, you can always find a walkthrough to get the answers to the puzzles and do it that way. 

My recommendation would be to play through normally the first time and once you've figured out the puzzles, then try it again on hardcore. 

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
You will definitely want to replay the game at least once. There's multiple ways to solve a bulk of the interactions (largely depending on what type of character you are), plus there's different mounts you can ride with different attributes (standard, sneaky, spooky and crazy), and three different companions -- so you'll be rewarded by playing through it again with a pretty varied experience.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Honestly, this is one of the better games I've played in a while, It's very well balanced and fun. If you like RPGS and puzzles and stories and humor, you'll love this.

34162899.review:
I had my skepticism coming into this. I was going to buy it either way, but given the state of Kingdom of Loathing in recent years I can't help but feel that Asymmetric have started to lose their touch with that game; from disbanding one of their lead writers (for a game that rides almost entirely on its writing) to revamping a quest that used to parody "collect all two dozen manual pages" into a quest where you ACTUALLY collect all two dozen manual pages... it's not the breath of fresh air it once was.

I'm happy to say that, in spite of or perhaps because of this, West of Loathing has been a pleasant surprise. I now wonder if part of the reason KoL has been on the wane is because they were pouring their best efforts into this instead. I've laughed more at the first half hour of this than I have at KoL in [i]years[/i] now, and the RPG-lite mechanics and combat system are done in a novel and compelling way (although the writing is still what you'll be playing for).

My primary gripes are that playing a completely black-and-white game for an extended period is slightly murderous on the eyes, and that it only seems to support a single save file... which is ludicrous given there's a fair number of things that you can permanently miss on one playthrough, and there are 3 character classes to play as. I'm also not convinced that there's actually enough depth to the game to give it much replayability, but at any rate I'm having fun so far.

34162546.review:
I'm a fan of KoL for a long time, despite having kept up with the game. Having a fresh experience, new story and setting, and completely revamped gameplay is such a great shot in the arm of the company, it's reminded me within the first few minutes of gameplay why I fell in love with it in the first place. It's sharp writing, unique humor that hits multiple angles, and strong RPG and exploration gameplay make it a fun solo experience that makes it a fun RPG. Its RPG challenge and wide selection of pop culture targets make it so expansive that it may not welcome newcomers to the RPG genre itself, and don't expect to catch every reference on the first reading as some of them are so subtly written as such to avoid overselling a joke.

If you aren't familiar with the MMO, basically KoL game is a text-based MMO with stick figure graphics. This game removes the MMO aspect, adding complete animations and character control to the experience, which makes exploration so much fun. Just like the original, each area is themed, and if you think you know what the joke is at the end, you are generally thrown off by a complete change of direction. How advant-garde! Seriously, where else are you going to find a game that references the Foo Fighters AND X-files in a single room, keeps it thematically appropriate, maintains the suspension of disbelief by keeping it within the realm of possibility of the world, tells a completely original joke that's only amplified by the understanding of the reference, AND continues to build its world and challengingly strategic RPG gameplay all in one? They never hesitate to waste a reference: the tooltips for the graphics options are Good, Bad, and Ugly. There's a ton of hidden gags that are too numerous to be called "easter eggs" that reward any and all exploration.

The game is challenging yet approachable. In accordance to old school RPG rules, you never really know the difficulty of an enemy until you engage it. This makes the beginning area extremely annoying once you open the map up, as you don't know whether an area can net you some good experience or have you face off enemies that can one shot you down. There's plenty of opportunity for leveling given that your stats are based on the XP earned rather than an arbitrary level threshold, and there's a lot of depth to gain from the choices you make. Fans of stat-building, and hardcore buff enthusiasts will feel right at home trying to min-max their stats for the most benefit using the spleen/liver effect system to potion or drink yourself to perfection. This game may seem simple, but it demands your attention in order to be effective and not waste all your money on health kits and free-use damage items.

34161783.review:
I spent the first twelve minutes of this game shooting clouds and tumbleweeds and getting a meat bounty of 9011.  I'm serious, it's not even funny.

As a long-time fan of Asymmetic Publications's...well, publications, I am well-aquainted with the weird, wonderful and wacky hijinks one can have with their wares. PSA: For those familiar with Kingdom of Loathing, skip the next few paragraphs, these are going to be for the newcomers.

To those that have never played Kingdom of Loathing (KoL), this game could can your laughter and sell it off on the open market for premium rates. Premium Canned Laughs. It is a thing. Asymmetic believes "If it isn't funny or story-building, it doesn't belong."  and that motto is proved through the dense liana of jokes, quips, minor cattle-prodding at grammar and spelling, bizzare, surreal and otherwise humorous interactions that spice the game in liberal quanitities.

If Fallout 4's ideology is "It's not the destination (or the dialogue), but the journey that's important", WoL gives Bethesda a Double-Fisted Skull Smashing pound to the noggin and proclaims in proud fashion, "You're an idiot." and proceeds to strip the padding out of boring searching for the next waypoint.  Travel is point-to-point with random encounters happing about once every travel, but they are quick interludes (that half-way decent Outfoxin' stats can resolve in most cases) in between the points of interest.

Every location has numerous interesting points to inspect; if it looks interesting, it's got something worth your time. Characters have depth to them, even if the dialogue can be linear at least it's not faking you out.  It's been a while that I've played a game where I want to talk to every NPC.

Combat is fluid and deeper than your usual fare with satisfying results.  Statistics are limited to three main stats and a few damage+ stats, so the initial difficulty curve is lower as you're getting into it.  The automatic leveling suggestions are well-thought out and give you the option to spend your exp elsewhere for a bit if you wish (or all the time, the game only slightly judges you for this.)

The game deserves the praise it gets and it's a solid investment of your money and time.  Why are you still reading this?  I mean, thanks for doing that, but buy the game already!  Go on, I'll only judge you if you take more than a minute to hit that "Add to Cart" button.  I mean it, I'll judge you. *stares in judgement*


To those that have played KoL and know the score, this is up to Jick's usual stratospheric standards.  Best ten bucks I've spent for any Loathing-related purchase.  I do have a Dancing Frog, but that's 2 Mr. A's so that doesn't count.

But you KNOW this already, so why are you reading this? You probably want the skinny on what's different, right?  You played the WoL path...buuuuut...something's gotta be different, right?

You bet your bottom meat there is:

Stats defend against themselves - Mustle to Mustle, Myst to Myst, and Moxie to Mojo; maybe it's them hellcows been chewin' on the fabric of reality.  This is the biggest change aside from...

Semi-grid-based combat - Positioning is important, but mostly for protecting yourself against ranged attacks.  Duck behind that barrel of beans, or beans in the shape of a barrel to keep stuff from shooting you in the <kneecap>.

Action Points are your MP - And you get your AP back at the end of every combat.

HP recovers at the end of combat - And it's a good thing it does...

Death comes on swift hooves - Did I mention the hellcows?  I'm sure I mentioned the hellcows.

Exp is a single resource - Instead of being split up into the substats you're used to, you just buy your stats with your accmulated exp.

No character levels - As there are no character levels in the West (guess they had a meeting and shot the guy that suggested it), you directly upgrate your levels in everything which includes...

Skills have individual levels - No more one-size-fits-all skills, if you want them to be good, you have to put your exp into it.

Food/Booze/Spleen gives buff effects last for a day - As such, your consumption is no longer about turn-gen, but what stats you want to buff that "day".  You can sleep, but that incriments...

The Day counter - guess there's a thing for speedrunners.  Wonder how that will work out in the future. I dunno, I just got this today!

Much Dialogue - Great speeching! Very talk! Must pat devs! Devs good bois.

Speak to Goblins! - No word on FARQUAR yet though...

There's enough the same that you'll feel comfortable slotting yourself into the world.  It breathes the same air as KoL does, but the Wild West has it's own flavor to it.

It's worth it.  Take that Mr. A money you were going to use and shove it in here. Asymmetric made this for you, after all.  They made it for others to get a glimpse of what KoL offers, but between the ghost pickles, Ellsbury (poor guy) and all the other subtle nods to KoLore, it was made for us first of all.  That Asymmetric made the game enjoyable for others to be able to play and feel included in is just Knob frosting on the Knob cake.

tl;dr: Buy it.  Yes, buy it now.

So, at first glance, this looks like a stick figure side scrolling RPG in a weird western setting.  That's what it looks like at second glance as well.  That's what it is.  But there's a little more going on.

West of Loathing is a new game from the fantastic and brilliant creators of Kingdom of Loathing, a long running browser based RPG.  If you've played and enjoyed, then I don't know why you're still reading this.  Go play WoL.  

If you have no idea what's going on, that's fine.  West of Loathing is an Western Themed RPG where you set out west to seek your fortune.  Along the way you'll encounter miners, minors, goblins, skeletons, dynamite hoarders, and pale (ghost) horses.  And that's just what I ran into today.  It's smart, it's simple, it's hilarious, and I'll probably go back to playing it after I finish this review.  I highly recommend this game to fans of humor, westerns, and stick figures.

34158562.review:
There's not much I can say here that hasn't already been covered well by release day reviews in The Escapist, Polygon, PC Gamer, Venture Beat, Pixel Related or Recombu, all of them absolutely glowing.  What I can tell you is that this made my face hurt.  Why?  I was laughing out loud so much my cheeks were sore the next day.  What I can tell you is that my wife banned me from playing the game after she went to bed, because the roaring laughter at a new spittoon gag or crazy dialog about a cow would wake her.  And what I can tell you is that I had hours and hours of fun (about 50 so far) solving all the puzzles and crazy, quirky side quests.

I don't 100% a lot of games but you can bet the farm I'm going to get every cheevo on this one.  Every piece of writing is the highly polished, subtle, droll humor you expect if you have played Kingdom of Loathing.  Chock full of references not just to American pop culture and nerd-friendly media, but also deep cuts in literature and tons of gaming tropes.  Everything from undergraduate D&D games to Skeleton fort is represented in hilarious fashion.

Polygon says that it's "a genuinely deep and hilarious game" and I can't overstate my agreement.  It's a huge game, bigger than you think before you buy it, bigger than you think when you start playing it, and bigger than you think when you finish your first playthrough.  Don't be deceived by the low price point, this is hours and hours of face-hurting levels of belly laughs and incredible fun.  The systems are fun, the puzzles have a great range of difficulty, and combat is satisfying and offers a diverse selection of available approaches.

If you like Kingdom of Loathing, if you like things that are funny, if you like nerdy or pop culture references, or if you just like silly walks or horrifically disgusting descriptions of spittoons, you'll love the game.   If you only like games that are in all purple colors and Japanese, you probably will not.

34157461.review:
When one of the first perks you get in the game, just from overly-examining stuff, is a purely aesthetic perk called "Stupid Walking", chances are you're probably in for a good game.  When each one of those walk cycles has their own unique sounds associated with them, you KNOW you're in for a good game.

West of Loathing is a RPG from the people who made Kingdom of Loathing, and shares its artstyle, humor, and some gameplay mechanics.  Yes, the artstyle is just stickfigures and black & white graphics, but it works, surprisingly.  Everything's well animated and detailed, despite the simplicity, giving it a certain nice charm.  The simplicity also helps for the UI, as there's very little clutter.  This helps, because your inventory gets -really- cluttered (which is a good thing, stick with me).

Gameplay is the standard "loot and talk to people" out of combat then "turn-based combat" combat.  Combat's simplistic, you and your ally take a turn, then your enemies.  Combat's rather easy, not only because it's easy to just out-stat your enemies with the various food, booze, and potion buffs, but also because combat items don't cost an action, thus allowing you to use as many as you need to finish off enemies.  There is a hard-mode, but I've yet to try it and see how combat's on it there.
The true meat of the game lies in the out of combat stuff.  There is a lot of things out in the West, and thus, a lot of writing.  Every item out of the hundreds of items has a small quip of description that's worth looking at, every location seems to be handcrafted with a purpose, and the dialogue is superb.  Still, there is a -lot- of writing, as said.  Between exploring eldritch horrors and necromantic power you shouldn't be tackling with, to a heartwarming relationship between a lass and man-cactus hybrid, it's all smart, well-written, and humorous.  The sheer volume of writing can be a slight turn off if that's not what you're into, but if you've read this far into the review, chances are you'd be the audience this game is selling to.

It's also rather nice that there's very little filler in this game.  I finished it in 7 hours, but I always felt like I was doing something in those seven hours.  Not like Skyrim or Fallout 4's generic caves and dungeons, everything seems to have it's own unique story or twist, and chances are you'll bump into a quest or someone that will point you towards something new. 
Not only that, but there's plenty of good puzzling to be had as well (most of it optional, if you're not the type, however), legit puzzles that get you Googling and searching about.  There's little grind as well, since there's plenty of just small flavor actions and text-encounters you have traveling about that grant you XP, though there are certain locations with infinite enemy spawners, in the off-chance you do want to grind.  

It's also pretty decent to replay.  The three different classes seem to play fairly differently, and there's a fair amount of different followers you can bring with you, each having different quips and dialogue, alongside the aforementioned hard mode.  There may be no need to actually replay the game, however, simply due to the sheer density of content available.

While West of Loathing doesn't do much new in terms of gameplay, it makes up for it far more with it's superb writing and charm.  It avoids most of the pitfalls and downsides of most typical RPG games, with very little need to grind, and very little feeling of grinding.

And only for 11 bucks?  That's ridiculous, it's not even funny.

34156797.review:
If you like Kingdom of Loathing you will like this.

If you have never heard of Kingdom of Loathing, you may as well look that up and go play it for free first. The gameplay elements here are pretty much the same but presented differently. With that being said, they are presented very well and even had details that caught me by surprise. The minimalistic design was part of Kingdom of Loathing's charm, and that is not lost in West of Loathing. The addition of animation is done in a way that fits the style perfectly. It just looks right.

What really made Kingdom of Loathing special though was the humor. Simply put, it was different. That same style of humor is present in West of Loathing. The writing, the atmosphere, even the menus have this absurd humor. It is often "reference-based" humor, but done in a way that you don't realize that you are missing a reference. You know how sometimes you can "feel" that a joke was intended but you missed the reference so it just felt awkward? That doesn't happen much in KoL and WoL. If you miss the reference you just don't notice, because it's done in a way that fits well with the rest of the game.

My most concise description though would be: it's like an open world rpg had sex with ms paint and then went through a fax machine and was written by comedians with learning disabilites.

34152578.review:
I'm 2 hours in so this is a first impressions review.

In this game you wander around an expansive 2D black and white animated wild west full of snakes and skeletons, reading very funny and silly descriptions and interacting with quirky characters, some of whom want you dead. There is turn based combat (if you want it) and a whole host of adventure game style collect-and-cash-in mechanics. The menus and traversal are all quick and intuitive and the art style and animation are consistent, irreverent, and joyful. The music evokes spaghetti westerns.

The standout so far is that there is very little filler in the world - towns, caves and chasms you explore are short and sweet, densely packed with different things to click on, loot and/or kill. I don't know how long the game is but from the map it seems a bounty of riches for the seven quid it cost me.

Warning: if you don't like reading text, this game is not for you. Why did I write text there? Who knows.

34151928.review:
EDIT: (10+ Hour Review) West of Loathing is a black and white adventure RPG where choices matter and dialogue is important. If you don't like reading and potentially having to memorize or soak up information to do any of the multitudes of sidequests or side activities this game is not for you. The RPG aspect itself is not hard and due to the free roam nature of the game you will often find yourself either smashing your opponents or dying in one hit(does not happen often) There are interesting game mechanics that force you to think about what to do with your day.(do I insult myself in the morning for the stat buff, or do I keep the extra life for potentially tough fights?) However despite the up and down balance of the game this is a hidden gem. There are many, many, many, so many passives and intrinsics to find. The dialogue is rich, well thought out and hilarious to boot and the game awards you for exploration and problem solving. Character customization is lacking but fun to do as it is done via a shooting gallery. However leveling up your chatracter is deep and offers many choices to specialize. You can also rely on the game to level for you if you just want to jump in and play without the hassle of all that. Overall if you're unwilling to retain or write down information, or take the time to read through dialogue(albeit funny) this is not the game for you.

(1 Hour Review)
After I fell off a turnip wagon, crab walked my way through a road apple and rolled into a saloon, I knew I was in the old west. 

The Cows have Come Home and the west isn't (as) safe anymore. ((was it actually ever safe?) well now it's even less safe and since it wasn't safe already we'll just say it's flat out dangerous(why are there so many people talking and are these parenthesis even nested properly?!))

West of loathing is an interactive story-driven satyrical take on the old west (and itself) in an alternate world where meat is currency and needles trade for dynamite or y'know, pick locks. (but you can't sew with them) Take on the role of a vicious Cow-Puncher, a mystical Beanslinger or the slippery tongued Snake Oil Salesman guy thing that I can't remember the name of and is anyone even reading this?! A tactical, adventure, rpg, visual novel for the whole family. Except that one uncle that everyone in your family says ate lead paint as a child and you're really inclined to believe them. This isn't for him, but it's definitely for you though so BUY IT NOW!

34151642.review:
If you like an RPG which is quirky and funny, then you're looking in the right place. Some people might already be familiar with the creators from their work on the browser-based game, Kingdom of Loathing. Others may be new to their style. If you are a veteran of Kingdom of Loathing, then you already know what to expect. Apply the very best qualities of that game to a Wild West setting, and that's West of Loathing. If you've not tried KoL before, then it can maybe serve as a free introduction to the kind of writing and art that you'll find here.

While West of Loathing may be in black and white, it seems incredibly vivid to look at. Not only is the line art great, but the animation really brings it to life. I've seen plenty of games in full colour which didn't look this good. It's also pleasantly fast paced, and feels good to play. I'm having a lot of fun with it!

34150953.review:
West of Loathing is the first and only game I've ever reviewed. I think there's an inherent bias in that I had played Kingdom of Loathing religiously when I was in high school and college, but the fact is that Asymmetric's sense of humor has only gotten more refined (and more absurd) with age.

If you're buying this game, it's going to be for the writing and the humor, but I was most surprised to see that I was actually intrigued by a number of plots I stumbled across in the game. The running gags and unexpected jokes always landed, but more importantly, I actually DID want to figure out where all the skeletons were coming from and how to stop the cows from murdering everyone.

I unlocked the ending cutscene with about 8 hours of playtime (across multiple playthroughs), but it was very clear I had no finished most of the major plotlines, so I'm going back to continue finishing everything to get the most completionist endings. Plus I'm already thinking about my next character, horse, and pardner choices for a 2nd playthrough. Without a doubt, I highly recommend this game.

39414810.review:
I didn't find myself loving this games as much as I thought I would - Imagine a South Park/Mario and Luigi style simple RPG with almost Fallout: New Vegas style exploration and quest solving set in an intentionally poorly drawn Wild West with the same art style from the Kingdom of Loathing online game. The combat is just fine and is pretty easy in normal mode, but is unremarkable. World exploration involve automatically walking between points in the world map with a chance to find new areas or have random encounters such as fights, npcs, or loot. The thing that kept me motivated to finish the game was the silly and zany pun based comedy - which will be hit or miss for you. I have to admit, the game didn't make me laugh as much as I hoped and I don't know if that is the result of "bad comedy" or just my mood when playing the game at the time, but I recommend playing the Kingdom of Loathing to get an idea what kind of comedy you'll get here.

[h1]It's a pretty decent RPG and it isn't a bad purchase, but if it's comedy styling doesn't do much for you, West of Loathing won't either.[/h1]

I was hesitant about this game initially. I have loved Kingdom of Loathing since the first year launched. An entire RPG around it? Would it feel repetitive and worn out?

Short answer: NO.

Long answer: NOOOOOOOOOOOO.

This game was a delight. It controlled beautifully and when the combat and travel started to get repetitive, there were settings to speed things up. Everything about this game was hilarious, from flavor text to quest lines to even the menu options. There were a few points I had to pause to stop laughing at how silly everything was.

The only issue I had was that the plot was kind of lacking. But this isn't really a game you play for a deep plot. 

I think I found most of the secrets and map locations and one very complete playthrough took 7 hours.

If you enjoy the quirky sense of humor that KOL had, this is a must buy. And do yourself a favor. Stick your hand in a few spittoons.

39094289.review:
West of Loathing is a silly game consisting of 3 things:

[b] 1 Turn based combat	[/b]
West of Loathing has turn based combat that is on a fight to fight basis. What I mean by that is that after every fight you get back all your health and action points (look at this more like mana). The objective is just to survive (win) the combat you are currently doing. This makes the combat quite challenging sometimes, since enemies deal a lot of damage and it’s all about action economy. There is a plethora of skills to use. Some that end you turn (mostly attacking) and some that don’t (mostly summoning or using a consumable). This makes the combat fun and engaging!
[b] 2 Puzzles	[/b]
There are 2 kinds of puzzles in West of Loathing. “area puzzles” that make you look around the area to find clue’s as to how to solve them, and “item puzzles” that bar your progress until you figure out how to obtain the necessary object. I am not a puzzle person but the puzzles in this game are great! They follow this weird logic that is present in the entire game, its completely silly but logic if you accept the silliness!
[b] 3 Humor	[/b]
Really that’s the third one? Yes! The entire game (down the options menu) is so seeped in jokes, puns and just damn silliness! This is going to be a personal preference, but man did I enjoy reading all the dialogue just for that humor. Very well written game! I think you can pick up really fast (after the first hour or so) if it is your kind of humor or not.

Graphics are what you see is what you get (stick figures …), but I do think that they are perfect for this game. Don’t think the game would be better if it where beautifully animated/hand drawn, that just wouldn’t fit …! The story is … silly, like I said before it’s completely silly but logic if you accept the silliness. And if you do that … surprisingly intriguing. (Aint gone win any prizes, but I found it compelling enough!)
All in all, a really enjoyable and silly game!

38995462.review:
Definitely the best open-world RPG I've played in a decade. Huge amount of places to explore, lots of quests, amazing quality of texts, etc. Can't wait to finish my first playthrough to start a second one, with a different class, companion and set of choices (in this game they actually matter!)

You know the biggest difference between this game and "open-world" games from, let's say, Bethesda?

There, they copy-paste and slightly rearrange the same prefabs, to create 150 variations of essentially the same few locations, with the same basic elements, same enemies etc., and ask you to believe that this is worth $60. You see a glowing and blinking nuclear reactor, and you know that it's exactly the same as other 20 reactors you've already looted. It will give you an item, and that's it. Nothing to look forward to.

Here, you can click on a foot locker you already looted and get a unique experience, because some guy with a really nice sense of humor spent some time on writing a unique joke just_for_this_one_object, just in case you'll click on it again after you've already looted it. You see a paper bag that looks identical to a few other ones you've seen in other places, and you look forward to the dialogue you'll click through because you know it's going to be unique and hilarious. You shiver in anticipation a little bit before interacting with any unfamiliar object, character or even an element of the background, because you know they will most likely do something that will make you, as a player, a little bit happier.

And this is definitely something worth paying for.

38983816.review:
I bought this game for the nostalgia, because I was a big player of the Kingdom of loathing years ago. Never expected the game to be as good as it is. It has no right to be as good as it is. Its just stickmen and word play, with enough depth to drown all of this years games combined.

This is the first game where I've actually started thinking about what I'll do for my next playthrough.

The world is packed, but not full of busy work, with many different encounters. In 8 hours I dont think I ever got the same random enounter twice, save for the generic "oh hey a crate" events. Everything is witty and fun and I recommend it at any price.

38978924.review:
Alguns cenários de ficção se tornaram tão marcados na memória coletiva do Ocidente que oferecem ampla possibilidade para a sátira. Personagens, locais e situações se tornaram tão frequentes que é fácil fazer piadas com a certeza de que elas serão compreendidas. Com isso em mente, West of Loathing, da Asymmetric Publications, escolheu um dos cenários mais batidos da cultura pop para criar seu RPG de humor pastelão: o Velho Oeste. Mas não deixe que os bonecos de palito e a perspectiva de piadas soem como simplicidade. West of Loathing é uma aventura extremamente bem escrita, e mesmo com todo o absurdo de sua narrativa, nunca se torna cansativo graças à maestria de seus escritores em criar uma das melhores experiências de humor em muitos anos.

------------------------------------------------------------------

This game is exactly what you would expect from the KoL crew. The main quest is fairly railroaded (sometimes literally), and completing all quests is also straightforward. The story is offbeat and choices you make during the game matter, albeit only a little bit.

The game is quite enjoyable and I would recommend it 100% to KoL fans and slightlylessthan100% to a non-KoL fan who would enjoy a casual JRPG experience set in the stick-y wild west.
